revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit | unit_name = 209th Corps | image=ANA 209 Corps SSI.svg | image_size = | caption=Emblem of the 209th Corps | start_date= September 2004
({{Age in years and months|2004|09|23}}){{cite web|url=https://www.stripes.com/news/building-an-army-for-afghanistan-1.29015|title=Building an army for Afghanistan|publisher=|accessdate=21 October 2018}} | country = {{Flag|Afghanistan}} | allegiance = | branch =[[File:Afghan National Army emblem.svg|23px]] [[Afghan National Army]] | type = [[Corps]] | role = | size = | nickname = Shaheen (Falcon){{cite web|url=https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/afghanistan/ana-orbat.htm|title=Afghan National Army (ANA) - Order of Battle|first=John|last=Pike|website=www.globalsecurity.org|accessdate=21 October 2018}} | command_structure = | garrison =[[Mazar-i-Sharif Province]], [[Afghanistan]]https://www.longwarjournal.org/multimedia/ANSF%20OOBpage4-ANA.pdf | garrison_label =Headquarters | battles =[[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] | commander1 = Brigadier General Amanullah Mobin | commander1_label = Current commander | commander2 = | commander2_label = | commander3 = | commander3_label = | commander4 = | commander4_label = | notable_commanders = | identification_symbol =[[File:ANA 209 Corps Flag.svg|border|100px]] | identification_symbol_label =Corps Flag }} The '''209th 'Shaheen' (Falcon) Corps''' is a corps, or military district, of the [[Afghan National Army]]. Its headquarters, Camp Shaheen, is at [[Mazar-i-Sharif]], [[Balkh Province]]. Since 25 April 2017, it has been commanded by Brigadier General Amanullah Mobin.{{cite web|url=http://mod.gov.af/en/page/corps/corps-of-209-shaheen|title=209 Shaheen Corps|publisher=Ministry of Defense|accessdate=30 September 2017}} It works closely with the German-led [[Resolute Support Mission]] [[TAAC North]], and has 1st Brigade at Mazar-i-Sharif and, it appears, a Second Brigade forming at [[Kunduz]]. A [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] solicitation for Kunduz headquarters facilities for the Second Brigade was issued in March 2008.FedBizOpps.gov, [https://www.fbo.gov/index?s=opportunity&mode=form&id=458c63fbfcbd7153893336cf7d4cac9d&tab=core&_cview=1&cck=1&au=&ck= 38—Y—Construction Services for the Second Battalion, 209th headqauters facilities, ANA Kunduz Installation Phase II, Kunduz, Afghanistan]. Retrieved August 2009. The corps is supported by the Mazar-i-Sharif Regional Support Squadron of the [[Afghan Air Force|AAF]], equipped with eight helicopters: four transport to support the Corps' commando battalion, two attack, and two medical transport helicopters.[http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2009/02/afghan_national_army.php Afghan National Army Air Corps: February 2009 Update – The Long War Journal] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wQIhm23B?url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2009/02/afghan_national_army.php |date=February 11, 2011 }} In October 2015, as a response to the [[Battle of Kunduz]], reports came that a new division would be formed in the area.{{Cite journal|last=Marty|first=Franz J.|date=10 February 2016|title=Isolated Outposts: Badakhshan sitrep|url=|journal=Jane's defence weekly (Vol 53, No. 6)|doi=|issn=0265-3818|pmid=|access-date=}} ==2017 Camp Shaheen attack== {{Main|2017 Camp Shaheen attack}} On 21 April 2017, [[Taliban]] fighters attacked Camp Shaheen killing at least 160{{cite news|last1=Mashal|first1=Mujib|last2=Cooper|first2=Helene|title=2 Top Afghanistan Military Officials Resign After Taliban Attack|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/24/world/asia/afghanistan-taliban-defense-minister-resigns.html?_r=0|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=The New York Times|date=24 April 2017}} Afghan soldiers and wounding many others. This makes the attack the bloodiest in the conflict with the Taliban since 2001 when they were removed from power.{{cite news|last1=Mashal|first1=Mujib|last2=Rahim|first2=Najim|title=‘A Shortage of Coffins’ After Taliban Slaughter Unarmed Soldiers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/22/world/asia/taliban-afghanistan-military-base-soldiers-killed.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=The New York Times|date=22 April 2017}} ==References== {{Afghan security forces}} [[Category:Corps of Afghanistan]] {{Afghanistan-mil-stub}}

{{Infobox language | name = Algerian Saharan Arabic | states = [[Algeria]], [[Niger]], [[Mali]] | region = southern | speakers = ca. 110,000 | date = 1996–1998 | ref = e18 | familycolor = Afro-Asiatic | fam2 = [[Semitic languages|Semitic]] | fam3 = [[Central Semitic languages|Central Semitic]] | fam4 = [[Arabic languages|Arabic]] | fam5 = [[Maghrebi Arabic|Maghrebi]] | iso3 = aao | map = Árabe sahariano.png | glotto = alge1240 | glottorefname = Algerian Saharan Arabic }}'''Algerian Saharan Arabic''' (also known as Saharan Arabic, Tamanrasset Arabic, Tamanghasset Arabic) is a structurally distinct [[variety of Arabic]] spoken by an estimated 100,000 people in [[Algeria]], predominantly along the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] border with the [[Atlas Mountains]]. It is also spoken by about 10,000 people in neighbouring regions of [[Niger]] and [[Mali]].
==See also== * [[Varieties of Arabic]] * [[Maghrebi Arabic]]
==References== {{Reflist}}{{Varieties of Arabic}}{{Languages of Algeria}}{{Semitic-lang-stub}}{{Algeria-stub}}{{Niger-stub}}{{Portal|Algeria|Languages}} [[Category:Languages of Algeria]] [[Category:Languages of Niger]] [[Category:Arabic languages]] [[Category:Maghrebi Arabic]]

{{Scandinavian military rank sidebar | image = [[File:Alikersantti kauluslaatta.svg|70px]] | imgText = Army | image2 = [[File:Alikersantti l hihalaatta.svg|40px]] | imgText2 = Navy | junior = [[Korpraali]] | junior2 = ([[Korpral]]) | senior = [[Kersantti]] | senior2 = ([[Sergeant (Sweden)|Sergeant]]) }} '''Alikersantti''' ([[Undersergeant]] in Swedish) is the lowest [[Finland|Finnish]] non-commissioned officer military rank.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.puolustusvoimat.fi/wcm/0802b480406f9674bed9ff66f99672d5/YlPalvO.pdf?MOD=AJPERES |title=Palvelusohjesääntö'' (General Regulations, in Finnish) |access-date=2013-02-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106165935/http://www.puolustusvoimat.fi/wcm/0802b480406f9674bed9ff66f99672d5/YlPalvO.pdf?MOD=AJPERES |archive-date=2011-01-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Alikersantti is one rank above a [[Korpraali]] ([[Lance-Corporal]]) and one below a [[Kersantti]] ([[Sergeant]]). A holder of this rank is typically a squad leader, assistant squad leader, gun section leader or a fighting vehicle commander.
== Obtaining the rank == Conscripts are first given basic military training for 2 months. About 30% are selected for NCO training (''aliupseerikoulu'' or ''AUK''), which lasts 4 months. Most ''alikersantti''s are posted to companies for squad leader duty. This is the most common conscript leader rank. Additionally, in many specialist branches with a 12-month service the rank is given automatically and the ''alikersantti'' is not given a command, e.g. assistant mechanic (''apumekaanikko'') in the Air Force.
It is also the highest rank that can be given to a soldier that has not completed any NCO course.
== History and related ranks== {{Empty section|date=July 2010}} == See also == * [[Finnish military ranks]]
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: Association of the Scientific Medical Societies in Germany

revision.text:
[[File:Awmflogo2010.png|thumb|right|Logo of the Association. ]] The '''Association of the Scientific Medical Societies in Germany''' ('''AWMF'''; ''Arbeitsgemeinschaft der Wissenschaftlichen Medizinischen Fachgesellschaften''), established in 1962<ref name="aufgaben-und-ziele"/> and located in Frankfurt am Main, is the umbrella organisation of more than 150 German [[medical association|medical societies]].
It coordinates the national program of [[medical guideline]]s.<ref name="leitlinien-kommission"/>
It is the German representative in the "Council for International Organizations of Medical Sciences [[CIOMS]]" at [[WHO]].<ref name="leitlinien-kommission"/>
The [[German Journal for Evidence and Quality in Healthcare ZEFQ]] is one of the organisation's official organs.
==References== <references> <ref name="aufgaben-und-ziele">{{cite web|url=http://www.awmf.org/die-awmf/aufgaben-und-ziele.html |title=Aufgaben und Ziele |language=de|access-date=2018-03-17}}</ref> <ref name="leitlinien-kommission">{{cite web|url=http://www.awmf.org/leitlinien/leitlinien-kommission.html |title=Ständige Kommission "Leitlinien" der AWM |language=de|access-date=2018-03-17}}</ref> </references>
==External links== *[http://www.awmf-online.de AOfficial Website] *[http://www.egms.de/ German Medical Science (GMS)] - "Open Access" Journal of AWMF
{{Authority control}}

{{for|the series of World War I battles|Battles of the Isonzo}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Isonzo |partof=the [[Roman-Germanic wars]] |image= |caption= |battle_name=Battle of Isonzo |date=28 August 489 |place=[[Isonzo]], near [[Aquileia]], modern {{ITA}} |result=Ostrogothic victory |combatant1=[[Heruls]]
[[Scirians]] |combatant2=[[Ostrogoths]]
[[Rugians]] |commander1=[[Odoacer]] |commander2=[[Theoderic the Great]] |strength1=20,000 |strength2=10,000 |casualties1=unknown |casualties2=unknown }} {{Campaignbox Conquest of Italy by Theodoric the Great}} The '''Battle of the Isonzo''', the '''Battle of the Aesontius''', or the '''Battle of the Isontius''' is the name given to the battle fought on August 28, 489 on the banks of the Isontius River, not far away from [[Aquileia]]. This river is now known as the [[Isonzo]] in [[Italian language|Italian]], and [[Soča]] in [[Slovene language|Slovene]]. This battle should not be confused with the 12 [[Battles of the Isonzo]] during [[World War I]]. [[Theoderic the Great]], king of the [[Ostrogoths]], in 489 opened his first campaign against [[Odoacer]] to wrest [[Italy]] from him. On 28 August, the two armies met on the banks of the Isontius. Theoderic defeated Odoacer, who retreated. A [[Battle of Verona (489)|second battle]] was fought at [[Verona]].{{cite book|author= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=xsQxcJvaLjAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+the+Goths#v=onepage&q=Bassianae%20Dengizich&f=false |title=History of the Goths |publisher=University of California Press |date=13 February 1990 |accessdate=5 April 2012|isbn=9780520069831 }} == Background == In 476, the barbarian warlord Odoacer founded the Kingdom of Italy as the first King of Italy, initiating a new era over Roman lands. Unlike most of the last emperors, he acted decisively. At the beginning of his reign he "slew Count Bracila at Ravenna that he might inspire a fear of himself among the Romans." He took many military actions to strengthen his control over Italy and its neighboring areas. He achieved a solid diplomatic coup by inducing the Vandal king Gaiseric to cede to him Sicily. Noting that "Odovacar seized power in August of 476, Gaiseric died in January 477, and the sea usually became closed to navigation around the beginning of November", F.M. Clover dates this cession to September or October 476. When Julius Nepos was murdered by two of his retainers in his country house near Salona (May 480), Odoacer assumed the duty of pursuing and executing the assassins, and at the same time established his own rule in Dalmatia. As Odoacer's position improved, Zeno, the Eastern Emperor, increasingly saw him as a rival. According to John of Antioch, Odoacer exchanged messages with Illus, who had been in revolt against Zeno since 484. Thus Zeno sought to destroy Odoacer and promised Theoderic the Great and his Ostrogoths the Italian peninsula if they were to defeat and remove Odoacer. Theoderic had his own reasons to agree to this offer, as he had enough experience to know (or at least suspect) that Zeno would not, in the long term, tolerate his independent power. When Theoderic rebelled in 485, he had in mind Zeno's treatment of Armatus. Armatus defected from Basilicus to Zeno in 476, and was made senior imperial general for life. Within a year, Zeno had him assassinated. == Battle and Aftermath == In 489, Theoderic led the Ostrogoths across the Julian Alps and into Italy. On 28 August, Odoacer met him at the Isonzo, only to be defeated. He withdrew to Verona, reaching its outskirts on 27 September, where he immediately set up a fortified camp. Theoderic followed him and three days later defeated him again. While Odoacer took refuge in Ravenna, Theoderic continued across Italy to Mediolanum, where the majority of Odoacer's army, including his chief general Tufa, surrendered to the Ostrogothic king. Theoderic had no reason to doubt Tufa's loyalty and dispatched his new general to Ravenna with a band of elite soldiers, "but Tufa changed sides, the Gothic elite force entrusted to his command was destroyed, and Theoderic suffered his first serious defeat on Italian soil.” Theoderic recoiled by seeking safety in Ticinum. Odoacer emerged from Ravenna and started to besiege his rival. While both were fully engaged, the Burgundians seized the opportunity to plunder and devastated Liguria. Many Romans were taken into captivity, and did not regain their freedom until Theoderic ransomed them three years later. == References == {{reflist}} '''Bibliography''' *{{cite book|last=Wolfram|first=Herwig|title=History of the Goths|publisher=University of California Press|year=1990|isbn=0-520-06983-8}} {{coord missing|Italy}} [[Category:480s conflicts|Isonzo 489]] [[Category:Battles involving the Ostrogoths|Isonzo 489]] [[Category:Battles involving Germanic peoples|Isonzo 489]] [[Category:Battles in Friuli-Venezia Giulia]] [[Category:Ostrogothic Kingdom]] [[Category:5th century in Italy]] [[Category:489]] [[Category:Theoderic the Great]] {{Battle-stub}} {{Europe-hist-stub}}

[[File:Doorway in Ben Youssef Madrasa.JPG|thumb|A small doorway in Ben Youssef Madrasa, [[Marrakech]]. The wooden doors are carved with a [[girih]] pattern of strapwork. The arch is surrounded with [[arabesque]]s; to either side is a band of [[Islamic calligraphy]], above colourful [[Islamic geometric patterns|geometric]] [[zellige]] tilework.]]
The '''Ben Youssef Madrasa''' was an [[Islam]]ic [[college]] in [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]], named after the [[Almoravid]] [[sultan]] [[Ali ibn Yusuf]] (reigned 1106–1142), who expanded the city and its influence considerably. It is the largest madrasa in all of Morocco.
The college was founded during the period of the [[Marinid]] (14th century) by the [[Marinid]] sultan [[Abu Al-Hasan Ali ibn Othman|Abu al-Hassan]] and allied to the neighbouring [[Ben Youssef Mosque]]. The building of the [[madrasa]] was re-constructed by the [[Saadi Dynasty|Saadian]] Sultan [[Abdallah al-Ghalib]] (1557–1574).<ref name=Raezer>{{Cite book |title=Morocco Revealed: Fez, Marrakech, Meknes and Rabat |last=Raezer |first=David |publisher=Approach Guides|year=2015 |isbn=1936614472 |pages=1931–2000}}</ref> In 1565 the works ordered by [[Abdallah al-Ghalib]] were finished, as confirmed by the inscription in the prayer room. Its 130 student dormitory cells cluster around a courtyard richly carved in [[cedrus|cedar]], [[marble]] and [[stucco]]. The carvings contain no representation of humans or animals as required by [[Islam]], and consist entirely of inscriptions and [[Islamic geometric patterns|geometric patterns]] such as star and petal designs in [[zellige]] tilework.<ref name=Broug2008>{{cite book |author=Broug, Eric |title=Islamic Geometric Patterns |publisher=[[Thames and Hudson]] |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-500-28721-7 |page=69}}</ref> This madrasa was one of the largest theological colleges in [[North Africa]] and may have housed as many as 900 students. One of its best known teachers was [[Mohammed al-Ifrani]] (1670-1745).<ref name=Raezer />
Closed down in 1960, the building was refurbished and reopened to the public as an historical site in 1982.
<gallery mode="nolines"> File:Ben Youseff Madressa.jpg|The courtyard of the madrasa, with the ablution pool a departure from earlier [[Marinid]] design, namely the absence of a fountain.<ref name=Raezer /> File:BenYoussefMadrasa plaster work.jpg|The plaster work of the [[Saadian]] period is more three-dimensional in nature with protruding pine-cone and arabesque motifs.<ref name=Raezer /> File:Medersa Ben Youssef, Marrakech (2846783625).jpg|[[Muqarnas]] vaulting File:Madrasa ben Yusuf mezquita. 03.jpg|Inside of the oration hall File:Madraza Ben Youssef, piso superior 02.JPG|The madrasa's student living quarters File:Medina of Marrakesh Medersa Ben Youssef interior detail.jpg|Mihrab with Darj w ktaf motifs and [[kufic]] script. </gallery>

{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Brazilians in Angola |image = |caption = |population = 20 000 |regions= [[Cabinda (city)|Cabinda]]{{·}}[[Luanda]]{{·}}[[Malanje]] |langs= [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] |rels= Predominantly [[Roman Catholicism]]
some [[Protestantism]]{{·}}[[Atheism]]{{·}}[[Religion in Brazil|Others]] |related= [[Brazilian diaspora]] }} There is a small but recognizable community of '''Brazilians in Angola''' consisting mainly of immigrants and expatriates from [[Brazil]]. There are an estimated 5,000 Brazilians registered in Angola, mainly working for construction, mining and agribusiness companies.[http://globalvoicesonline.org/2008/08/17/angola-brazil-a-culture-shock-divide/: Angola, Brazil - A culture shock divide]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Overview== With the formation of the CPLP ([[Community of Portuguese Language Countries]]) in 1996 there has been an increase of Brazilian immigrants to Angola. Many of these are said to be [[white Brazilian|white Brazilians]] looking for economic investments in the largely undeveloped country.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mixedindifferentshades.net/africa/angola.html|title=mixedindifferentshades.net|website=www.mixedindifferentshades.net|language=en|access-date=2017-07-21}} According to the "Association of Brazilian Companies in Angola", the presence of Brazilian companies in Angola has expanded on a par with the increase in trade. The number of Brazilian companies in Angola has increased by 70 percent over the last few years since 2002. The firms are mainly involved in public works, sales of construction materials, project design, real estate and food.{{Cite web|url=http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=40040|title=Inter Press Service {{!}} News and Views from the Global South|website=ipsnews.net|access-date=2017-07-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904014903/http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=40040|archivedate=2008-09-04|df=}} Brazilians are thus beginning to flock to a country which, in spite of the historical and linguistic links, was virtually an unknown quantity until just over a decade ago. The 5,000 Brazilians registered in Angola live and work in the provinces of [[Cabinda Province|Cabinda]], [[Lunda Norte]] and [[Malanje]] as well as in the capital, [[Luanda]]. ==See also== {{portal|Angola|Brazil}} * [[Angola–Brazil relations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Brazilian diaspora}} {{Ethnic groups in Angola}} [[Category:Brazilian diaspora by country|Angola]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Angola|Brazilian]] [[Category:Brazilian diaspora in Africa|Angola]] [[Category:Angolan people of Brazilian descent| ]] {{Angola-stub}}

'''Służba Celna''' {{lang-en|Customs Service}}) is a Polish [[customs service]] department, subordinate to the Polish [[Ministry of Finance (Poland)|Ministry of Finance]]. In its current form, the Polish Customs Service was created in 1999, from the reformed Central Board of Customs (''Główny Urząd Ceł''). Like most custom services worldwide, the Polish Customs Service is responsible for assessing and collecting customs duties and taxes, exercising customs control, primarily at the Poland's borders. Służba Celna is a [[law enforcement agency]]. ==Ranks and rank insignia== The Polish government decided in 2009 that the customs service rank structure would be adapted to the rank structure of the [[Policja|Police]] and [[Border Guard (Poland)|Border Guard]]. ===Ranks=== {| width="100%" border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- !width = "33%" bgcolor = "#FFDEAD"|Rank !width = "33%" bgcolor = "#FFDEAD"|Corps !width = "33%" bgcolor = "#FFDEAD"|Equivalent rank in the Border Guard |- |Aplikant celny |Customs rank and file |''szer. revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox single | Name = Dreamer | Cover = | Caption = | Artist = [[Alisa Kozhikina]] | from Album = | A-side = | B-side = | Released = 28 September 2014 | Format = | Recorded = Summer 2014 | Genre =[[Pop music|Pop]] | Length =3:00 | Label = | Writer = [[Maxim Fadeev]], [[Alisa Kozhikina]], [[Olga Seryabkina]] | Producer = | Certification = | Chart position = | Last single = | This single = | Next single = | Misc = {{External music video|1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ITKXaRGRinU "Dreamer"] on YouTube}} {{Infobox song contest entry|embed=yes | junior = yes | song = {{Flagicon|Russia}} "Dreamer" | image = | caption = | year = 2014 | country = Russia | artist = [[Alisa Kozhikina]] | as = | with = | language = | languages =[[Russian language|Russian]], [[English language|English]] | composer = [[Alisa Kozhikina]], [[Maxim Fadeev]] | lyricist = [[Alisa Kozhikina]], [[Olga Seryabkina]] | place = 5th | points = 96 | lyrics = | prev_year = 2013 | prev =Mechtay | prev_link =Mechtay | next =Mechta (Dream) | next_link =Mechta (Dream) }} }} '''"Dreamer"''' ({{lang-ru|Белые ангелы |translit=Belyye angely}}) is a song by [[Russians|Russian]] child singer [[Alisa Kozhikina]], who won the first season of ''[[The Voice Kids (Russia)|The Voice Kids]]'' of [[Russia]]. It [[Russia in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|represented Russia]] at the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014]] in [[Marsa, Malta]], placing 5th with 96 points.{{cite web|title=Watch Alisa Kozhikina's song "Dreamer"|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=watch_alisa_kozhikinas_song_little_dreamer|last=Fisher|first=Luke James|publisher=EBU|accessdate=28 September 2014|date=28 September 2014}} The song is a ballad where [[Alisa Kozhikina|Alisa]] sings about being free like a bird and she dreams away during the music video. ==Music video== There are two existing versions for the music video. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QcHz8aAJ-6s The first one] is filmed in black-and-white and features [[Alisa Kozhikina|Alisa]] singing at a park and taking balloons from a woman passing by at the second chorus and in the end, she is seen singing with violinists in the background. This version is the official version that was released in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest YouTube channel on September 28, 2014.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QcHz8aAJ-6s [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xSxIHkM7XWI The second version] of the music video was aired on Russia's Karusel TV and was uploaded to [[Alisa Kozhikina]]'s official page on [https://www.facebook.com/AlisaKozhikinaRu Facebook] on November 8, 2014 https://www.facebook.com/video.php?v=728950033854445 and this version features [[Alisa Kozhikina|Kozhikina]] singing against a black backdrop which later turns into a backdrop with stars and going up on a small flight of stairs for the second stanza of the song, still singing against a backdrop with stars and towards the last chorus, [[Alisa Kozhikina|Kozhikina]] now sings against a backdrop of a white cloth that was unveiled with a projection of clouds and the music video ends with her going back to singing against a black backdrop as in the beginning of the video. The second version of the music video also comes with karaoke-style lyrics displayed at the bottom on the video. ==Performances== ===Junior Eurovision 2014=== {{Main|Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014}} [[Alisa Kozhikina|Alisa]] performed [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IgHyJ5dfcck "Dreamer"] at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]] in [[Marsa, Malta]] on 15 November 2014. Russia performed 13th on the evening, after Armenia and before Serbia. At the close of the voting, Dreamer placed 5th with 96 points.{{cite news|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2014/11/09/junior-eurovision-2014-running-order-draw-half/65490/|title=Junior Eurovision 2014: Running order draw determines first half, second half acts |work=wiwibloggs |location=Malta |date=9 November 2014|first=Mario|last=Melvan }} == Charts == {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !Chart (2014) !Peak
position |- | [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] ([[Tophit|Top Hit]] Weekly General){{cite web|url=http://www.tophit.ru/tracks/view/59714|title=Алиса Кожикина - Dreamer|publisher=[[Tophit|TopHit]]|accessdate=2016-05-26|language=Russian}} |style="text-align:center;"| 313 |- | CIS ([[Tophit|Top Hit]] Weekly Audience Choice) |style="text-align:center;"| 188 |- | [[Russia]] ([[Tophit|Top Hit]] Weekly Russia) |style="text-align:center;"| 1765 |} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014}} {{Russia in Junior Eurovision}} [[Category:Russian songs]] [[Category:Junior Eurovision Song Contest]] [[Category:2014 singles]] [[Category:2014 songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Maxim Fadeev]] [[Category:Songs written by Olga Seryabkina]] [[Category:Alisa Kozhikina songs]] {{Eurovision-stub}} {{Russia-stub}}

An '''emporium''' (plural: '''emporia''') was one of the trading settlements that emerged in [[Northwestern Europe]] in the 6th to the 7th centuries and persisted into the 9th century. Also known in English as '''[[-wich town|wics]]''', they were characterised by their peripheral locations, usually on the shore at the edge of a kingdom, their lack of infrastructure (containing no churches) and their short-lived nature. By 1000, the emporia had been replaced by the revival of European towns. Examples include [[Dorestad]], [[Quentovic]], Gipeswic, Hamwic, and Lundenwic (for which see [[Anglo-Saxon London]]). Their role in the economic history of [[Western Europe]] remains debated. Their most famous exponent has been the British archaeologist [[Richard Hodges (archaeologist)|Richard Hodges]].
==See also== *[[-wich town]]
==References== * Anderton (Mike) (ed.). Anglo-Saxon Trading Centres: Beyond the Emporia.Cruithne Press. Glasgow. 1999. * Crabtree (Pamela J.) (ed.). Medieval Archaeology: An Encyclopedia. Routledge. New York. 2013. 448p. * Hill (D.), Cowie (R.) (eds.). Wics: The Early Medieval Trading Centres of Northern Europe. Sheffield. 2001 * Hodges (Richard). 'Towns and Trade in the Age of Charlemagne'. 2001. * Hodges (Richard). Dark Age Economics, Origins of Towns and Trade AD 600–1000. Duckworth. London. 1989. 230p. * Loveluck (Christopher). Northwest Europe in the Early Middle Ages, c. AD 600–1150: A Comparative Archeology. Cambridge University Press. Cambridge. 2013. 488p. * Loveluck (Christopher). Rural settlement, lifestyles and social change in the later first millennium AD: Anglo–Saxon in its wider context. Excavations at Flixborough Volume 4. Oxbow Books. Oxford. 2007. 194p. * Sherman (Heidi Michelle). Barbarians Come to Market: The Emporia of Western Eurasia from 500 BC to AD 1000 (PhD Dissertation). ProQuest. Ann Arbor. 2008. 369p. * Valante (Mary A.). Vikings in Ireland, Settlement, Trade and Urbanisation. Four Courts Press. Dublin. 2008. 216p. * Verhulst (Adriaan E.). 'Emporium', in ''Lexikon des Mittelalters'', III, München - Stuttgart, [1977]-1999, klm. 1897-1898. (online bekeken) * Verhulst (Adriaan E.). The Rise of Cities in North–West Europe. Cambridge University Press. Cambridge. 1999. 174p.
[[Category:History of Europe]]

page.title: International Society for Developmental Origins of Health and Disease

revision.text:
'''International Society for Developmental Origins of Health and Disease''' (A International Society for [[DOHaD]]), a [[non-profit organization]] proposed by David Barker, was set up in 2003 and made up of various [[scientists]] and clinicians (31main [[council]] members), whose main research concentration is the [[etiology (medicine)|developmental origins]] of health and [[disease]].
==External links== *[http://www.mrc.soton.ac.uk/dohad/index.asp?page=1 Official Website of International Society for Developmental Origins of Health and Disease]
[[Category:International medical and health organizations]]

<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:kalmartrissan.jpg|thumb|A Kalmartrissan yo-yo]] --> '''Kalmartrissan''' is a brand of [[yo-yo]] which has been manufactured since 1932.<ref name="museum">[http://www.kalmarlansmuseum.se/1/1.0.1.0/51/1/?item=art_art-s1/1592 "Kalmartrissan" och andra "trissor"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821071826/http://www.kalmarlansmuseum.se/1/1.0.1.0/51/1/?item=art_art-s1%2F1592 |date=2010-08-21 }}, County Museum of Kalmar {{sv icon}}</ref><ref name = "dn">"Kalmartrissan snurrar vidare", ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'' 19 December 2012 (not available in the on-line edition) {{sv icon}}</ref><ref name = "sr">[http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=86&artikel=38136 Kalmartrissan fyller 70 år], [[Sveriges radio]], 25 January 2002, retrieved 22 March 2013 {{sv icon}}</ref> The company that makes it, [[Elfverson & Co.]], is located in [[Påryd]], about {{convert|30|km}} from [[Kalmar]] in [[Småland]], [[Sweden]]. In the early 1930s, Gösta Elfverson saw a yo-yo during a trip to [[England]], and brought the idea with him to Sweden, where the manager of Elfverson's factory developed a unique construction: the Kalmartrissan is made in wood and in a single piece, rather than two pieces that have been glued together.<ref name= "svd">[http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/kand-trissa-har-spunnit-i-70-ar_1034127.svd Känd trissa har spunnit i 70 år] ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' 28 January 2002, retrieved 22 March 2013 {{sv icon}}</ref><ref name = museum />
The toy is manufactured from [[beech]] wood, and bears a logo depicting the [[Kalmar Castle|Castle of Kalmar]], one of the best kept [[renaissance]] [[castle]]s in Europe.<ref name = museum /> "Trissa" is a Swedish word meaning [[pulley]], which is sometimes used informally for other round objects, including yo-yos.
Between 150,000 and a million yo-yos of the Kalmartrissan brand are manufactured every year in Sweden.<ref name = svd />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.elfverson.se/trissan/page1.htm Kalmartrissan, official website]
[[Category:Yo-yos]]
{{Sweden-stub}}
[[sv:Kalmartrissan]]

page.title: Law on Higher Education and Research (France)

revision.text:
{{Expand French|Loi relative à l'enseignement supérieur et à la recherche|date=July 2015}}
The '''Law on Higher Education and Research''' of July 22, 2013 replaced laws promulgated by the previous French government in 2006 and 2007 (for example the law on [[Liberties and Responsibilities of Universities]]) regarding the organization and autonomy of universities and other research and higher education institutions in France.
During the 2012 French presidential election, [[François Hollande]] promised to review and improve conditions for undergraduate and graduate education and research in French universities. Shortly after the election, [[Geneviève Fioraso]], minister for higher education and research, launched an assessment process led by an independent committee in dialogue with the university community. The committee presented a report on December 17, 2012 containing 135 recommendations. Some of the proposals received criticism, but these formed the basis for the new law presented to the [[National Assembly (France)]] in March 2013, and adopted into law July 22, 2013. Other than a dispute over the introduction of English into university courses there was little public debate.
== Contents of the Law == The first title of the new law concerned general principles such as teaching in the French language,<ref group="law">Articles L121-3 of the code de l’Éducation, modified by article 2 of the law on higher education and research</ref> or the use of [[Free software]]. Ministers in charge of Higher Education and Research would be responsible for 5-year strategic national plans.
The law describes national limits on general professional degrees and minimal percentages on professional graduates and technological graduates. Students have a right to access more selective university programs if they have sufficiently high grades on their [[baccalauréat]] (high school graduation exam).
=== Geographic coordination ===
The law provides that “coordination is organized by only one establishment of higher education for a given territory [academic or interacademic]".
Every institution of higher education needed to plan for the following to establish this coordination: * merging with one or more other institutions * participating in an [[association of universities and higher education institutions]], * associating in another form of [[Établissement public à caractère scientifique, culturel et professionnel|public scientific, cultural or professional establishment (EPSCP)]].<ref group="law">Articles L718-2 and L718-3 of the code de l’Éducation, created by article 62 of the law on higher education and research</ref>
The Association of universities and higher education institutions (communauté d’universités et établissements) is a new type of EPSCP created by this law; at the same time, the [[Pôle de recherche et d'enseignement supérieur|pôles de recherche et d'enseignement supérieur]] (PRES), the [[Réseau thématique de recherche avancée|réseaux thématiques de recherche avancée]] (RTRA) and the [[Établissement public de coopération scientifique|établissements publics de coopération scientifique]] (EPCS), created by the 2006 law on research coordination are discontinued.<ref group="law">Article 66 of the law on higher education and research</ref>
Now there are [[Groups of universities and institutions|Communities of universities and institutions]] (COMUE).
==See also== * [[Pôle de recherche et d'enseignement supérieur]], PRES (2007−2013) * [[Groups of universities and institutions|Communities of universities and institutions]], ''Communautés d’Universités et Établissements'' (COMUE) (est. 2013)
==References == {{reflist|group="law"}}
;Text of the law * {{cite web|url=http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichLoiPreparation.do?idDocument=JORFDOLE000027197524&type=general|title=Dossier législatif - Projet de loi relatif à l’enseignement supérieur et à la recherche (ESRJ1304228L)}} ----
{{Public universities and higher education institutes in France}} {{Scientific research in France}}

page.title: List of English words from indigenous languages of the Americas

revision.text:
This is a '''list of [[English language]] words borrowed from [[indigenous languages of the Americas]]''', either directly or through intermediate European languages such as [[Spanish language|Spanish]] or [[French language|French]]. † indicates a link to a definition of the word. It does not cover names of ethnic groups or place names derived from indigenous languages.
Most words of Native American/First Nations language origin are the [[common name]]s for indigenous flora and fauna, or describe items of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] or [[First Nations]] life and culture. Some few are names applied in honor of Native Americans or First Nations peoples or due to a vague similarity to the original object of the word. For instance, [[Sequoioideae|sequoias]] are named in honor of the Cherokee leader [[Sequoyah]], who lived 2,000 miles east of that tree's range while the [[kinkajou]] of South America was given a name from an unrelated North American animal 2,000 miles to the north.
==Words from Algonquian languages== {{Wiktionary category|type=with [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian language]] origins|category=Algonquian derivations}}
Since Native Americans and First Nations peoples speaking a language of the [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian group]] were generally the first to meet English explorers and settlers along the [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]], many words from these languages made their way into English.
In addition, a great number of place names in [[North America]] are of Algonquian origin, for example: '''Mississippi''' (cf. [[Illinois language|Illinois]] ''mihsisiipiiwi'' and [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] ''misiziibi'', "great river," referring to the [[Mississippi River]])<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.myaamiaproject.org/project/map.php |title=Historical Landscapes of the Miami |work=Myaamia Project |author=Klak, Thomas |accessdate=2007-03-29 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928031958/http://www.myaamiaproject.org/project/map.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-28}}</ref><ref name="CDMO">Nichols, John, and Earl Nyholm. 1995. ''A Concise Dictionary of Minnesota Ojibwe''. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press</ref> and '''Michigan''' (cf. Illinois ''meehcakamiwi'', Ojibwe ''Mishigami'', "great sea," referring to [[Lake Michigan]]).<ref name="CDMO" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museum.state.il.us/muslink/nat_amer/post/htmls/popups/id_lang_places.html|title=Some Illinois Words:Places|website=www.museum.state.il.us}}</ref> Even [[Canadian province]]s and [[U.S. state]]s, districts, counties and municipalities bear Algonquian names, such as [[Québec]], [[Saskatchewan]], [[Nantucket, Massachusetts]], [[Naugatuck, Connecticut]], [[Wyoming]], [[District of Keewatin]], [[Outagamie County, Wisconsin]] and [[Chicago, Illinois]], or Algonquian-derived names, such as [[Algoma (word)|Algoma]].
In addition, a number of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas]] groups are known better by their Algonquian [[exonym]]s, rather than by their [[Exonym and endonym|endonym]], such as the [[Eskimo]] (see below), [[Ho-Chunk|Winnebago]] (perhaps from [[Potawatomi language|Potawatomi]] ''winpyéko'', "(people of the) dirty water"),<ref name="Cthreeninenine">Campbell (1997:399)</ref> [[Sioux]] (ultimately from [[Anishinaabe language|Ottawa]] ''naadowesiwag''),<ref name="Cthreeninenine" /> [[Assiniboine people|Assiniboine]] ([[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''asiniibwaan'', "stone Sioux")<ref name="CDMO" /> and [[Chipewyan]] ([[Cree language|Cree]] ''čīpwayān'', "(those who have) pointed skins or hides").<ref>Campbell (1997:395)</ref>
;[[Apishamore]] [[wikt:apishamore|†]]: From a word in an Algonquian language meaning "something to lie down upon"<ref>{{cite journal |last=Chamberlain |first=Alexander F. |title=Algonkian Words in American English: A Study in the Contact of the White Man and the Indian |journal=The Journal of American Folklore |volume=15 |issue=59 |pages=240–267 |year=1902 |doi=10.2307/533199 |jstor=533199}}</ref> (c.f. [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''apishimon'').<ref name="CDMO" /> ;[[Atamasco lily]] [[wikt:atamasco lily|†]]: Earlier "attamusca", from [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]].<ref>RHD (1987:129)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/a/a0492200.html |title=Atamasco lily |publisher=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |accessdate=2007-03-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927013401/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/a/a0492200.html |archivedate = 2007-09-27}}</ref> ;[[Babiche]] [[wikt:babiche|†]]: From [[Míkmaq language|Míkmaq]] ''ápapíj'' (from ''ápapi'', "cord, thread", [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*aʔrapa·pyi'', from ''*aʔrapy-'', "net" + ''*-a·by-'', "string".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=babiche |title=Babiche |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2008-07-07}}</ref> ;[[Caribou]] [[wikt:caribou|†]]: From [[Míkmaq language|Míkmaq]] ''qalipu'', "snow-shoveler" (from ''qalipi'', "shovel snow", [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*maka·ripi-'').<ref>RHD (1987:315-16)</ref> ;[[Caucus]] [[wikt:caucus|†]]: The etymology is disputed: two possible sources are an Algonquian word for "counsel", 'cau´-cau-as´u'; or the Algonquian ''cawaassough'', meaning an advisor, talker, or orator.<ref>Wilson, James (1999). ''The Earth Shall Weep''. New York City, NY: Atlantic Monthly Press. pp. 104–105. {{ISBN|0-87113-730-5}}.</ref> ;Chinkapin [[wikt:chinkapin|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] ''chechinquamins'',<ref>RHD (1987:361)</ref> reconstituted as {{IPA|*/t͡ʃiːht͡ʃiːnkweːmins/}}, the plural form.<ref>Siebert (1975:323)</ref> ;[[Chipmunk]] [[wikt:chipmunk|†]]: Originally "chitmunk," from [[Anishinaabe language|Odawa]] ''jidmoonh''<ref name="EOCOD">Rhodes, Richard A. 1985. ''Eastern Ojibwa–Chippewa–Ottawa Dictionary''. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter</ref> {{IPA|/t͡ʃɪtmő/}} (c.f. [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''ajidamoo(nh)''),<ref name="CDMO" /> "[[American red squirrel]]". ;[[Cisco (fish)|Cisco]] [[wikt:cisco|†]]: Originally "siscowet," from [[Ojibwe language]] ''bemidewiskaawed'' "greasy-bodied [fish]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/c/c0369900.html |title=Cisco |publisher=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |accessdate=2007-05-01 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070714061230/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/c/c0369900.html |archivedate = 2007-07-14}}</ref> ;[[Eskimo]] [[wikt:Eskimo|†]]: From [[Montagnais language|Old Montagnais]] ''aiachkimeou'' ({{IPA|[aːjast͡ʃimeːw]}}; modern ''ayassimēw''), meaning "snowshoe-netter" (often incorrectly claimed to be from an [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word meaning "eaters of raw [meat]"), and originally used to refer to the [[Mi'kmaq people|Mikmaq]].<ref>Campbell (1997:394)</ref><ref>Goddard, Ives (1984). "Synonymy". In "Arctic", ed. David Damas. Vol. 5 of ''Handbook of North American Indians'', ed. William C. Sturtevant. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution, pp. 5:5–6</ref> ;[[Hackmatack]] [[wikt:hackmatack|†]]: From an Algonquian language ''akemantak'' (c.f. [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] ''aagimaandag''), "[[snowshoe]] boughs".{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} ;[[Hickory]] [[wikt:hickory|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <pocohiquara>, "milky drink made with hickory nuts".<ref>RHD (1987:900)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/h/h0186800.html |title=Hickory |publisher=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |accessdate=2007-03-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070611182631/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/h/h0186800.html |archivedate = 2007-06-11}}</ref> ;[[Hominy]] [[wikt:Hominy|†]]: From Powhatan <uskatahomen>/<usketchaumun>, literally "that which is treated", in this case "that which is ground/beaten".<ref>RHD (1987:915)</ref> ;[[Husky]] [[wikt:Husky|†]]: Ultimately from a variant form of the word "Eskimo" (see above).<ref>{{OEtymD|husky|accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> ;[[Kinkajou]] [[wikt:kinkajou|†]]: From an Algonquian word meaning "wolverine" (c.f. [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] ''kwingwaage'', [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''gwiingwa'aage''),<ref name="CDMO" /> through French ''quincajou''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50126844 |title=Kinkajou |publisher=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> ;[[Kinnikinnick]] [[wikt:Kinnikinnick|†]]: From [[Lenape language|Unami Delaware]] {{IPA|/kələkːəˈnikːan/}}, "mixture" (c.f. Ojibwe ''giniginige'' "to mix something animate with something inanimate"),<ref name="CDMO" /> from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*kereken-'', "mix (it) with something different by hand".<ref>RHD (1987:1058)</ref> ;[[Mackinaw cloth|Mackinaw]] [[wikt:mackinaw|†]]: From ''michilmackinac'', from [[Menomini language|Menomini]] ''mishilimaqkināhkw'', "be large like a snapping turtle",{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} or from [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] ''mishi-makinaak'', "large snapping turtle" with French ''-ile-'', "island".{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} ;[[Moccasin]] [[wikt:moccasin|†]]: From an Algonquian language, perhaps [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <mockasin>,<ref>Bright (2004:291)</ref> reconstituted as {{IPA|*/mahkesen/}}<ref>Siebert (1975:381)</ref>(c.f. [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''makizin'',<ref name="CDMO" /> [[Míkmaq language|Míkmaq]] ''mɨkusun'',<ref>{{OEtymD|moccasin|accessdate=2008-07-07}}</ref> from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*maxkeseni'').<ref>RHD (1987:1235)</ref> ;[[Moose]] [[wikt:moose|†]]: From [[Eastern Abenaki language|Eastern Abenaki]] ''moz'', reinforced by cognates from other Algonquian languages<ref>Bright (2004:297)</ref><ref name="RHDmoose">RHD (1987:1247)</ref> (e.g. [[Massachusett language|Massachusett/Narragansett]] ''moos'',<ref name="RHDmoose" /> [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''moo(n)z'',<ref name="CDMO" /> [[Lenape language|Lenape]] ''mus'' 'elk'<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.talk-lenape.org/detail.php?id=5249 |title=mus |work=Lenape Talking Dictionary |accessdate=2010-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315214331/http://www.talk-lenape.org/detail.php?id=5249 |archivedate=2012-03-15 |df= }}</ref>), from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*mo·swa''.<ref name="RHDmoose" /> ;[[Mugwump]] [[wikt:mugwump|†]]: From "mugquomp", a shortening of [[Massachusett language|Massachusett]] <muggumquomp>, "war chief" ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*memekwa·pe·wa'', from ''*memekw-'', "swift" + ''*-a·pe·'', "man").<ref>RHD (1987:1261)</ref> ;[[Muskellunge]] [[wikt:muskellunge|†]]: Ultimately from Ojibwe ''maashkinoozhe'',<ref name="CDMO" /> "ugly [[pike (fish)|pike]]" (c.f. ''ginoozhe'', "pike"). ;[[Muskeg]] [[wikt:muskeg|†]]: From Cree ''maskēk'', "swamp"<ref>Bright (2004:304)</ref> ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*maškye·kwi'').<ref name="RHDtwo">RHD (1987:1268)</ref> ;[[Muskrat]] [[wikt:muskrat|†]]: A [[Folk etymology|folk-etymologized]] reshaping of earlier "musquash", from [[Massachusett language|Massachusett]] (c.f. [[Western Abenaki language|Western Abenaki]] ''mòskwas''), apparently from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*mo·šk'', "bob (at the surface of the water)" + ''*-exkwe·-'', "head" + a derivational ending).<ref name="RHDtwo" /> ;[[Opossum]] [[wikt:opossum|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <apasum>/<opussum>/<aposoum>, "white dog-like animal",<ref>RHD (1987:1359)</ref> reconstituted as {{IPA|*/aːpassem/}}<ref>Siebert (1975:363)</ref> (c.f. [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''{{IPA|*waːp-aʔθemwa}}'', "white dog").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.krysstal.com/display_feedback.php?ftype=Borrow&fblock=4 |title=Comments by Michael McCafferty on "Readers' Feedback (page 4)" |publisher=The KryssTal |accessdate=2007-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/00332796 |title=Opossum |publisher=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> ;[[Papoose]] [[wikt:papoose|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] <papoòs><ref name="AHd">[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]]</ref> or [[Massachusett language|Massachusett]] <pappouse>, "baby".<ref>RHD (1987:1405)</ref> ;[[Pecan]] [[wikt:pecan|†]]: From [[Illinois language|Illinois]] ''pakani'' (c.f. [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''bagaan''),<ref name="CDMO" /> "[[Nut (fruit)|nut]]", from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*paka·ni''.<ref>RHD (1987:1427)</ref> ;[[Pemmican]] [[wikt:pemmican|†]]: From [[Cree language|Cree]] ''pimihkān'', from ''pimihkēw'', "to make grease" ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*pemihke·wa'', from ''*pemy-'', "grease" + ''-ehke·'', "to make").<ref>RHD (1987:1432)</ref> ;[[Persimmon]] [[wikt:persimmon|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <pessemins>/<pushemins>, reconstituted as {{IPA|*/pessiːmin/}}.<ref>Siebert (1975:367)</ref> While the final element reflects [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*-min'', "fruit, berry", the initial is unknown.<ref>RHD (1987:1445)</ref> ;[[Pipsissewa]] [[wikt:pipsissewa|†]]: From [[Abenaki language|Abenaki]] ''kpipskwáhsawe'', "flower of the woods".<ref name="AHd" /><ref>RHD (1987:1474)</ref> ;[[Pokeweed]] [[wikt:pokeweed|†]]: Probably from "puccoon" (see below) + "weed".<ref name="AHd" /> ;Pone [[wikt:pone|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <poan>/<appoans>, "something roasted" (reconstituted as {{IPA|*/apoːn/}})<ref>Siebert (1975:320)</ref> (c.f. [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] ''abwaan''),<ref name="CDMO" /> from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*apwa·n''.<ref>RHD (1987:1503)</ref> ;[[Powwow]] [[wikt:powwow|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] ''powwaw'', "[[shaman]]" ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*pawe·wa'', "to dream, to have a vision").<ref>Bright (2004:397)</ref> ;[[Puccoon]] [[wikt:puccoon|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <poughkone>,<ref name="AHd" /> reconstituted as {{IPA|*/pakkan/}}<ref>Siebert (1975:369)</ref> (c.f. [[Lenape language|Unami Delaware]] {{IPA|[pɛːkɔːn]}}, 'red dye; the plant from which dye is made').<ref>RHD (1987:1563)</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=pèkòn|url=http://www.talk-lenape.org/detail.php?id=8395|website=Lenape Talking Dictionary|publisher=Delaware Tribe of Indians|accessdate=July 29, 2015}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> ;Pung: A low box-like sleigh designed for one horse. Shortened form of "tom-pung" (from the same etymon as "toboggan") from an Algonquian language of Southern New England.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=pung |title=Pung |accessdate=2007-03-11 |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]]}}</ref> ;[[Ceratopogonidae|Punkie]] [[wikt:punkie|†]]: Via [[Dutch language|Dutch]], from [[Lenape language|Munsee]] {{IPA|[ponkwəs]}} ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*penkwehsa'', from ''*penkw-'', "dust, ashes" + ''*-ehs'', a [[diminutive]] suffix).<ref>RHD (1987:1568)</ref> ;[[Quahog]] [[wikt:quahog|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] <poquaûhock>.<ref>RHD (1987:1578)</ref> ;[[Quonset hut]] [[wikt:quahog|†]]: From an Algonquian language of southern New England, possibly meaning "small long place" (with <qunni->, "long" + <nowiki><-s-></nowiki>, [[diminutive]] + <-et>, [[locative]]).<ref>Bright (2004:406)</ref> ;[[Raccoon]] [[wikt:raccoon|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <arahkun>/<aroughcun>,<ref>RHD (1987:1590)</ref> tentatively reconstituted as {{IPA|*/aːreːhkan/}}.<ref>Siebert (1975:370)</ref> ;[[Sachem]] [[wikt:sachem|†]]: From an Algonquian language of southern New England,<ref>RHD (1987:1688)</ref> c.f. [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] <nowiki><sâchim></nowiki> ([[Eastern Algonquian languages|Proto-Eastern Algonquian]] ''*sākimāw'', "chief").<ref name="Godd">Goddard, Ives (1978). "Eastern Algonquian languages", in "Northeast", ed. Bruce G. Trigger. Vol. 15 of ''Handbook of North American Indians'', ed. William C. Sturtevant. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution, pg. 75</ref> ;[[Sagamore (title)|Sagamore]] [[wikt:sagamore|†]]: From [[Eastern Abenaki language|Eastern Abenaki]] ''sakəma'' (c.f. Narragansett <nowiki><sâchim></nowiki>), "chief", from [[Eastern Algonquian languages|Proto-Eastern Algonquian]] ''*sākimāw''.<ref name="Godd" /> ;[[Shoepac]] [[wikt:shoepac|†]]: From [[Lenape language|Unami Delaware]] {{IPA|[t͡ʃipahkɔ]}} "shoes" (singular {{IPA|[t͡ʃiːpːakw]}}), altered on [[Folk etymology|analogy]] with English "shoe".<ref>RHD (1987:1768)</ref> ;[[Skunk]] [[wikt:skunk|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Massachusett]] <squnck>{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*šeka·kwa'', from ''*šek-'', "to urinate" + ''*-a·kw'', "fox").<ref>Bright (2004:452-453)</ref> ;[[Squash (fruit)]] [[wikt:squash|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] <askútasquash>.<ref name="RHDthree">RHD (1987:1850)</ref> ;[[Squaw]] [[wikt:squaw|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Massachusett]] <squa> (c.f. [[Cree language|Cree]] ''iskwē'', [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''ikwe''),<ref name="CDMO" /> "woman", from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*eθkwe·wa''.<ref name="RHDthree" /> ;[[Succotash]] [[wikt:succotash|†]]: From [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] <msíckquatash>, "boiled whole kernels of corn" ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*mesi·nkwete·wari'', singular ''*mesi·nkwete·'', from ''*mes-'', "whole" + ''*-i·nkw-'', "eye [=kernel]" + ''-ete·'', "to cook").<ref>RHD (1987:1899)</ref> ;[[Tabagie (room)|Tabagie]] [[wikt:tabagie|†]]: From Algonquin ''tabaguia''.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uz11AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA178 | title=Africa and the Discovery of America, Volume 2 | publisher=Innes & Sons | accessdate=April 5, 2013 | author=Wiener, Leo| year=1922 }}</ref> ;[[Terrapin]] [[wikt:terrapin|†]]: Originally "torope," from an [[Eastern Algonquian languages|Eastern Algonquian language]], perhaps [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] (reconstituted as {{IPA|*/toːrepeːw/}})<ref>Siebert (1975:394)</ref> (c.f. [[Lenape language|Munsee Delaware]] {{IPA|/toːlpeːw/}}),<ref name="Bright 2004:489">Bright (2004:489)</ref> from [[Eastern Algonquian languages|Proto-Eastern Algonquian]] ''*tōrəpēw''.<ref>RHD (1987:1960)</ref> ;[[Toboggan]] [[wikt:toboggan|†]]: From [[Mi'kmaq language|Míkmaq]] ''topaqan''<ref name="RHD 1987:1990">RHD (1987:1990)</ref> or Maliseet-Passamaquoddy {{IPA|/tʰaˈpakən/}}<ref>Bright (2004:499)</ref> ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*weta·pye·kani'', from ''*wet-'', "to drag" + ''*-a·pye·-'', "cordlike object" + ''*-kan'', "instrument for").<ref name="RHD 1987:1990" /> ;[[Tomahawk (axe)|Tomahawk]] [[wikt:tomahawk|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <tamahaac> ([[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*temaha·kani'', from ''*temah-'', "to cut" + ''*-a·kan'', "instrument for").<ref>RHD (1987:1993)</ref> ;[[Totem]] [[wikt:totem|†]]: From [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''nindoodem'', "my totem" or ''odoodeman'', "his totem," referring to a [[Anishinaabe clan system|kin group]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/totem |title=Totem |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2008-12-25}}</ref> ;[[Tuckahoe (disambiguation)|Tuckahoe]]{{disambiguation needed|date=October 2018}} [[wikt:tuckahoe|†]]: From [[Powhatan language|Powhatan]] <tockawhoughe>/<tockwhough>/<taccaho>, "root used for bread", reconstituted as {{IPA|*/takwahahk/}}<ref>Siebert (1975:397)</ref> (perhaps from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*takwah-'', "pound (it)/reduce (it) to flour").<ref>RHD (1987:2033)</ref> ;[[Tullibee]] [[wikt:tullibee|†]]: From Old Ojibwe {{IPA|*/otoːlipiː/}}<ref>RHD (1987:2034)</ref> ([[Anishinaabe language|modern]] ''odoonibii'').<ref name="CDMO" /> ;[[Wampum]] [[wikt:wampum|†]]: Earlier "wampumpeag", from [[Massachusett language|Massachusett]], and meaning "white strings [of beads]" (c.f. [[Maliseet]]: ''wapapiyik'',<ref>Francis & Leavitt. 2008. A Passamaquoddy–Maliseet Dictionary. Orono: University of Maine Press. Page 588.</ref> [[Eastern Abenaki language|Eastern Abenaki]] ''wápapəyak'', [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''waabaabiinyag''),<ref name="CDMO" /> from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*wa·p-'', "white" + ''*-a·py-'', "string-like object" + ''*-aki'', plural.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=wampumpeag |title=Wampumpeag |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref><ref>RHD (1987:2140)</ref> ;[[Wanigan]] [[wikt:wanigan|†]]: from Ojibwa ''waanikaan'', "storage pit"<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/wanigan Wanigan] American Heritage Dictionary of English Language, Fourth Edition, 2000</ref> ;[[Elk|Wapiti]] (elk) [[wikt:wapiti|†]]: From [[Shawnee language|Shawnee]] ''waapiti'', "white rump" (c.f. [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''waabidiy''),<ref name="CDMO" /> from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*wa·petwiya'', from ''*wa·p-'', "white" + ''*-etwiy'', "rump".<ref>RHD (1987:2141)</ref> ;[[Wigwam|Wickiup]] [[wikt:wickiup|†]]: From [[Fox language|Fox]] ''wiikiyaapi'', from the same [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] etymon as "wigwam" (see below).<ref>RHD (1987:2172)</ref> ;[[Wigwam]] [[wikt:wigwam|†]]: From [[Eastern Abenaki language|Eastern Abenaki]] ''wìkəwam'' (c.f. [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] ''wiigiwaam''),<ref name="CDMO" /> from [[Proto-Algonquian language|Proto-Algonquian]] ''*wi·kiwa·Hmi''.<ref>RHD (1987:2173)</ref> ;[[Woodchuck]] [[wikt:woodchuck|†]]: Reshaped on [[Folk etymology|analogy]] with "wood" and "chuck", from an Algonquian language of southern New England (c.f. [[Massachusett language|Narragansett]] <ockqutchaun>, "woodchuck").<ref>RHD (1987:2186)</ref>
==Words from Nahuatl== {{Wiktionary category|type=with [[Nahuatl language]] origins|category=Nahuatl derivations}} :''Unless otherwise specified, [http://sites.estvideo.net/malinal/ Dictionnaire de la langue nahuatl classique] is among the sources used for each etymology'' Words of [[Nahuatl language|Nahuatl]] origin have entered many European languages. Mainly they have done so via [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. Most words of Nahuatl origin end in a form of the Nahuatl "[[Classical Nahuatl grammar#Nouns|absolutive suffix]]" (''-tl'', ''-tli'', or ''-li'', or the Spanish adaptation ''-te''), which marked unpossessed nouns.
;[[Achiote]] [[wikt:achiote|†]]: from ''āchiotl'' {{IPA-nah|aːˈt͡ʃiot͡ɬ}} ;[[Atlatl]] [[wikt:atlatl|†]]: from ''ahtlatl'' {{IPA-nah|ˈaʔt͡ɬat͡ɬ}} ;[[Avocado]] [[wikt:avocado|†]]: from ''āhuacatl'', "avocado" or "testicle" {{IPA-nah|aːˈwakat͡ɬ}} ;[[Axolotl]] [[wikt:atlatl|†]]: ''āxōlōtl'', from ''ā-'', "water" + ''xōlōtl'', "male servant"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/axolotl |title=Axolotl |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-04-27}}</ref> {{IPA-nah|aːˈʃoːloːt͡ɬ}} ;[[Cacao bean|Cacao]] [[wikt:cacao|†]] and cocoa [[wikt:cocoa|†]]: from ''cacahuatl'' {{IPA-nah|kaˈkawat͡ɬ}} ;[[Chayote]] [[wikt:chayote|†]]: from ''chayohtli'' {{IPA-nah|t͡ʃaˈjoʔt͡ɬi}} ;Chia [[wikt:chia|†]]: from ''chian'' <!-- Can't find this one. Does not sound like a Nahuatl noun. "chiyantli" is a seed in Nahuatl, but the wiktionary link claims this is a Mexican plant. -Ephert --> <!-- [http://whp.uoregon.edu/dictionaries/nahuatl/index.lasso] has "chian" as a Nahuatl word for "chia" itself -sche --> ;[[Chicle]] [[wikt:chicle|†]]: from ''tzictli'' {{IPA-nah|ˈt͡sikt͡ɬi}} ;[[Chile pepper|Chili]] [[wikt:chili|†]]: from ''chīlli'' {{IPA-nah|ˈt͡ʃiːlːi}} ;Chipotle[[wikt:chipotle|†]]: from ''chilpoctli'' meaning "smoked chili" ;[[Chocolate]] [[wikt:chocolate|†]]: Often said to be from Nahuatl ''xocolātl''<ref name="AHd" /> or ''chocolātl'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/chocolate |title=Chocolate |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref> which would be derived from ''xococ'' "bitter" and ''ātl'' "water" (with an irregular change of ''x'' to ''ch'').<ref>Karttunen, Frances (1983). ''An Analytical Dictionary of Nahuatl''. Austin: University of Texas Press, p. 54.</ref> However, the form ''xocolātl'' is not directly attested, and ''chocolatl'' does not appear in Nahuatl until the mid-18th century. Some researchers have recently proposed that the ''chocol-'' element was originally ''chicol-'', and referred to a special wooden stick used to prepare chocolate.<ref>Dakin, Karen and Wichmann, Søren (2000). "Cacao and Chocolate: An Uto-Aztec perspective." ''Ancient Mesoamerica'', vol. 11, pp.55–75.</ref> ;[[Copal]] [[wikt:copal|†]]: from ''copalli''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?book=Dictionary&va=copal|title=Definition of COPAL|website=www.merriam-webster.com}}</ref> ;[[Coyote]] [[wikt:coyote|†]]: from ''coyōtl'' ;[[Epazote]] [[wikt:epazote|†]]: from ''epazōtl'' ;[[Guacamole]] [[wikt:guacamole|†]]: from ''āhuacamōlli'', from ''āhuaca-'', "avocado", and ''mōlli'', "sauce" ;[[Hoatzin]] [[wikt:hoatzin|†]]: from ''huāctzin''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/hoatzin|title=Definition of HOATZIN|website=www.merriam-webster.com}}</ref> ;[[Jicama]] [[wikt:jicama|†]]: from ''xicamatl'' ;[[Mesquite]] [[wikt:mesquite|†]]: from ''mizquitl'' {{IPA-nah|ˈmiskit͡ɬ}} ;[[Mezcal]] [[wikt:mezcal|†]]: from ''mexcalli'' {{IPA-nah|meʃˈkalːi}} ''metl'' {{IPA-nah|met͡ɬ}} and ''ixcalli'' {{IPA-nah|iʃˈkalːi}} which mean 'oven cooked agave.'<ref name="What Is Mezcal">What is Mezcal? [http://www.elmezcal.org/general/what-is-mezcal Elmezcal.org]</ref> ;[[Mole (sauce)|Mole]] [[wikt:mole|†]]: from ''mōlli'' {{IPA-nah|ˈmoːlːi}}, "sauce" ;[[Nopal]] [[wikt:nopal|†]]: from ''nohpalli'' {{IPA-nah|noʔˈpalːi}}, "prickly pear cactus" ;[[Ocelot]] [[wikt:ocelot|†]]: from ''ocēlōtl'' {{IPA-nah|oːˈseːloːt͡ɬ}} ;[[Peyote]] [[wikt:peyote|†]]: from ''peyōtl'' {{IPA-nah|ˈpejoːt͡ɬ}}. Nahuatl probably borrowed the root ''peyō-'' from another language, but the source is not known.<ref>Campbell (1997:403, n. 53)</ref> ;[[Pinole]] [[wikt:pinole|†]]: from Nahuatl ''pinolli'', via Spanish ;[[Quetzal]] [[wikt:quetzal|†]]: from ''quetzalli'' {{IPA-nah|keˈt͡salːi}}, "[[quetzal]] feather".<ref>RHD (1987:1585)</ref> ;[[Sapodilla]] [[wikt:sapodilla|†]]: from ''tzapocuahuitl'' ;[[Sapota]] [[wikt:sapota|†]]: from ''tzapotl'' {{IPA-nah|ˈt͡sapot͡ɬ}} ;[[Shack]] [[wikt:shack|†]]: possibly from ''xahcalli'', "grass hut", by way of [[Mexican Spanish]].<ref name="AHd" /><ref>[http://www.bartleby.com/61/75/S0307500.html shack] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310162701/http://www.bartleby.com/61/75/S0307500.html |date=2007-03-10 }}</ref> {{IPA-nah|ʃaʔˈkalːi}} ;[[Sotol]] [[wikt:sotol|†]]: from ''tzotolli''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com/;jsessionid=E6BF4AAFFFF95839033C8DA68A58B067?authRejection=true&url=%2Fview%2FEntry%2F185039%3FredirectedFrom%3Dsotol|title=Home : Oxford English Dictionary|publisher=}}</ref> ;[[Taco]]: from ''tlahco: half or in the middle'' ;[[Tamale]] [[wikt:tamale|†]]: from ''tamalli'' {{IPA-nah|taˈmalːi}} ;[[Tequila]]: from ''téquitl: work; tlan: place'' ;[[Tule]] [[wikt:tule|†]]: from ''tōllin'' {{IPA-nah|ˈtoːlːin}}, "reed, bulrush" ;[[Tomato]] [[wikt:tomato|†]]: from ''tomatl'' {{IPA-nah|ˈtomat͡ɬ}}
==Words from Quechua== :''Unless otherwise specified, [http://www.zompist.com/indianwd.html Words in English from Amerindian Languages] is among the sources used for each etymology''
A number of words from [[Quechua language|Quechua]] have entered English, mostly via Spanish, adopting Hispanicized spellings.
;[[Ayahuasca]] [[wikt:ayahuasca|†]]: from ''aya'' "corpse" and ''waska'' "rope", via Spanish ''ayahuasca'' ;[[Cachua]] [[wikt:cachua|†]]: from ''qhachwa'' ;[[Chuño]] [[wikt:chuño|†]]: from ''ch'uñu'' ;[[Coca]] [[wikt:coca|†]]: from ''kuka'', via Spanish ''coca'' ;[[Cocaine]] [[wikt:cocaine|†]]: from ''kuka'' (see above), probably via French ''cocaïne'' ;[[Condor]] [[wikt:condor|†]]: from ''kuntur'', via Spanish ''cóndor'' ;[[Gran Chaco]] [[wikt:Gran Chaco|†]]: from ''chaku'', "hunt" ;[[Guanaco]] [[wikt:guanaco|†]]: from ''wanaku'' ;[[Guano]] [[wikt:guano|†]]: from ''wanu'' via Spanish ''guano'' ;[[Inca]] [[wikt:Inca|†]]: from ''Inka'' "lord, king" ;[[Jerky (food)|Jerky]] [[wikt:jerky|†]]: from ''ch'arki'', via Spanish ''charquí'' ;[[Lagniappe]] [[wikt:lagniappe|†]]: from ''yapay'', "add, addition", via Spanish ''la yapa'' (with the [[definite article]] ''la''). ;[[Lima bean|Lima]] [[wikt:lima|†]]: from ''rimay'', "speak" (from the name of [[Lima, Peru|the city]], named for the ''Rimaq'' river ("speaking river")) ;[[Llama]] [[wikt:llama|†]]: from ''llama'', via Spanish ;[[Mashua]] [[wikt:mashua|†]]: from ''maswa'' ;[[Pampa]] [[wikt:pampa|†]]: from ''pampa'', "a large plain", via Spanish ;[[Pisco]] [[wikt:pisco|†]]: from ''pisqu'', "bird" ;[[Puma (genus)|Puma]] [[wikt:puma|†]]: from ''puma'', via Spanish ;[[Quinine]] [[wikt:quinine|†]]: from ''kinakina'', via Spanish ''quina'' ;[[Quinoa]] [[wikt:quinoa|†]]: from ''kinwa'', via Spanish ''quinoa'' ;Soroche [[wikt:soroche|†]]: from ''suruqchi'' or ''suruqch'i'', "[[Altitude sickness]]"<ref>[http://homepage.ntlworld.com/robert_beer/Vocabulario%20comparativo%20Quechua%20cuzqueno%20Quechua%20boliviano%20-%2022%20Apr%2006.PDF Vocabulario Comparativo Quechua Cuzqueño-Quechua {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111226192019/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/robert_beer/Vocabulario%20comparativo%20Quechua%20cuzqueno%20Quechua%20boliviano%20-%2022%20Apr%2006.PDF |date=2011-12-26 }}([[PDF]])</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/translation/Quechua/suruqch%2527i |title=Suruqch'i |work=Webster's Online Dictionary }}</ref> ;[[Vicuña]] [[wikt: vicuña|†]]: from ''wik'uña'', via Spanish ''vicuña''
==Words from [[Eskimo–Aleut languages]]==
; [[Anorak]] [[wikt:anorak|†]]: from [[Kalaallisut language|Greenlandic Inuit]] ''annoraaq''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Anorak|title=the definition of anorak|website=www.dictionary.com}}</ref> ; Chimo [[wikt:chimo|†]]: from the [[Inuktitut]] word ''saimo'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᓴᐃᒧ]] {{IPA-iku|sa.i.ˈmo}}, a word of greeting, farewell, and [[Toast (honor)|toast]] before drinking.<ref name="note2">[http://www.billcasselman.com/cwod_archive/chimo.htm Bill Casselman's ''Canadian Word of the Day'' entry for Chimo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102181049/http://billcasselman.com/cwod_archive/chimo.htm |date=2010-01-02 }}</ref> Used as a greeting and cheer [[Canadian Military Engineers#Chimo|by the Canadian Military Engineers]], and more widely in some parts of Southern Ontario and Western Canada, particularly in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan {{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} ; [[Igloo]] [[wikt:igloo|†]]: from [[Inuktitut]] ''iglu'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᐃᒡᓗ]] {{IPA-iku|iɣ.ˈlu}})<ref name="CED">Foretescue, Michael, Steven Jacobson, and Lawrence Kaplan (1994). ''Comparative Eskimo Dictionary, with Aleut Cognates''. Fairbanks: Alaska Native Language Center</ref> ; Ilanaaq [[wikt:ilanaaq|†]]: [[Inuktitut]] ''ilanaaq'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᐃᓚᓈᒃ]] {{IPA-iku|i.la.naːk}}), "friend". Name of the logo for the [[2010 Winter Olympics#Marketing|2010 Winter Olympics]] ; [[Inukshuk|Inuksuk]] [[wikt:inukshuk|†]]: from [[Inuktitut]] ''inuksuk'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᐃᓄᒃᓱᒃ]] {{IPA-iku|i.nuk.ˈsuk}})<ref name="CED" /> ; [[Kayak]] [[wikt:kayak|†]]: from [[Inuktitut]] ''qajaq'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᖃᔭᖅ]] {{IPA-iku|qa.ˈjaq}})<ref name="CED" /> ; [[Malamute]] [[wikt:malamute|†]]: from [[Inupiaq language|Inupiaq]] ''Malimiut'', the name of an Inupiaq subgroup<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=malamute|title=the definition of malamute|website=www.dictionary.com}}</ref> ; [[Mukluk]] [[wikt:mukluk|†]]: from [[Yupik language|Yupik]] ''maklak'' ({{IPA|[makɬak]}}), "[[bearded seal]]"<ref name="CED" /> ; [[Nanook]] [[wikt:nanook|†]]: from [[Inuktitut]] word for polar bear ''Nanuq'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᓇᓄᒃ]] {{IPA-iku|na.ˈnuq}}),<ref name=livingdict>{{cite web|url=http://www.livingdictionary.com/term/viewTerm.jsp?term=49169844050 |title=nanuq|work=Asuilaak Living Dictionary|accessdate=2007-11-17}}</ref> "polar bear", made famous in English due to a 1922 documentary [[Nanook of the North]], featuring a man with this name. ; [[Nunatak]] [[wikt:nuntak|†]]: from [[Greenlandic language|Greenlandic Inuit]] '' nunataq''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/nunatak|title=Definition of NUNATAK|website=www.merriam-webster.com}}</ref> ; [[Umiaq]] [[wikt:umiaq|†]]
==Words from [[Arawakan languages]]==
;[[Anole]] [[wikt:anole|†]]: from an [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan language]], or possibly [[Cariban languages|Cariban]], by way of [[French language|French]] ''anolis''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/anole |title=Anole |publisher=[[Merriam Webster]]'s Online Dictionary |accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref><ref>Campbell (1997:11)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/a/a0320600.html |title=Anole |work=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |publisher=Yourdictionary.com |accessdate=2007-03-29 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070323220610/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/a/a0320600.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-03-23}}</ref> ;[[Barbecue]] [[wikt:barbecue|†]]: from an [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan language]] of [[Haiti]] ''barbakoa'', "framework of sticks",<ref>{{OEtymD|barbecue|accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref> via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''barbacoa''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50017490 |title=Barbecue |publisher=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref> ;[[Buccaneer]] [[wikt:buccaneer|†]]: from an [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan language]] ''buccan'', "a wooden frame on which Tainos and Caribs slowly roasted or smoked meat",via [[French language|French]] ''boucane''.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://en.mikipedia.org/wiki/Buccaneer#Etymology |accessdate= 2017-12-28 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> ;[[Cacique]] or cassique [[wikt:cacique|†]]: from Taino ''cacike'' or Arawak ''kassequa'' "chieftain"<ref>Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary, http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cacique, 2008. Retrieved 1 July 2008</ref> ;[[Caiman]] [[wikt:caiman|†]]: from a [[Maipurean languages#Northern Maipurean|Ta-Maipurean language]], "water spirit" (c.f. [[Garifuna language|Garifuna]] {{IPA|[aɡaiumã]}}),<ref>Taylor, Douglas. (1980). "A Note on the Derivation of the Word Cayman." ''International Journal of American Linguistics'' '''46''':47-48</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/c/c0020200.html |title=Caiman |work=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |publisher=On yourdictionary.com |accessdate=2007-04-02 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070827201103/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/c/c0020200.html |archivedate = 2007-08-27}}</ref> though possibly ultimately of African origin.<ref>{{OEtymD|caiman|accessdate=2009-06-21}}</ref> ;[[Canoe]] [[wikt:canoe|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]] via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''canoa''.<ref>Bright (2004:80)</ref> ;[[Cassava]] [[wikt:cassava|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]] ''caçabi'', "manioc meal", via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] or [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/cassava |title=Cassava |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref> ;[[Cay]] [[wikt:cay|†]]: from Taino, by way of Spanish ''cayo''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=key |title=Key |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-08-06}}</ref> ;[[Guava]] [[wikt:guava|†]]: from an Arawakan language, by way of Spanish ''guayaba''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/guava |title=Guava |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-08-06}}</ref> ;[[Hammock]] [[wikt:hammock|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]], via Spanish ''hamaca''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/hammock |title=Hammock |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-08-06}}</ref> ;[[Hurricane]] [[wikt:hurricane|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]] ''hurakán'', via [[Spanish language|Spanish]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/hurricane |title=Hurricane |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref> ;[[Iguana]] [[wikt:iguana|†]]: from an [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan]] language ''iwana''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/iguana |title=Iguana |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50111621 |title=Iguana |publisher=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |accessdate=2007-08-06}}</ref> ;[[Macana]] [[wikt:macana|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]] ''macana'' via Spanish. ;[[Maize]] [[wikt:maize|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]] ''mahís'', by way of Spanish.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/00299980 |title=Maize [[wikt:mangrove|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]], via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''mangle'' or [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''mangue''.<ref>Bright (2004:265)</ref> ;[[Papaya]] [[wikt:papaya|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/00341304 |title=Papaya |publisher=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |accessdate=2007-08-06}}</ref> ;[[Potato]] [[wikt:potato|†]]: from the [[Taíno language|Taino]] word for "papa", via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''patata''.<ref>Bright (2004:395)</ref> ;[[Savanna]] [[wikt:savanna|†]]: from [[Taíno language|Taino]] ''zabana'', via [[Spanish language|Spanish]].<ref>RHD (1987:1707)</ref> ;[[Tobacco]] [[wikt:tobacco|†]]: probably from an [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan language]], via |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/yucca |title=Yucca |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref>
==Words from [[Tupi–Guaraní languages|Tupi-Guaraní]]==
;[[Agouti]] [[wikt:agouti|†]]: from [[Tupian languages|Tupi–Guaraní]] ''akutí'', via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] aguti through [[French language|French]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/a/a0147100.html |title=Agouti |work=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |publisher=Yourdictionary.com |accessdate=2007-03-29 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070129092432/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/a/a0147100.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-01-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/agouti |title=Agouti |publisher=Dictionary.com |accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/agouti |title=Agouti |publisher=[[Merriam Webster]]'s Online Dictionary |accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref> ;[[Cashew]] [[wikt:cashew|†]]: from [[Tupi language|Tupí]] ''acaîu,'' via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] caju.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/cashew|title=the definition of cashew|website=www.dictionary.com}}</ref> ;[[Capybara]] [[wikt:capybara|†]]: from [[Guarani language|Guaraní]] ''kapibári'' 'the grass eater ' via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] capivara through [[French language|French]]. ;[[Catupiry]] [[wikt:catupiry|†]]: from [[Guarani language|Guaraní]] ''katupyry'' via [[Portuguese language|Brazilian Portuguese]].<ref>Ayala, Valentín (2000). ''Gramática Guaraní''. Asunción: Centro Editorial Paraguayo S.R.L.</ref> ;[[Cayenne]] [[wikt:cayenne|†]]: from [[Tupi language|Tupí]] ''kyinha'' via [[French language|French]].<ref>Bright (2004:84)</ref> ;[[Cougar]] [[wikt:cougar|†]]: ultimately corrupted from [[Guarani language|Guaraní]] ''guaçu ara''.<ref>Bright (2004:124)</ref> ;[[Jaguar]] [[wikt:jaguar|†]]: from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] jaguar through [[French language|French]] {{IPA|/jaˈwar-/}},.<ref name="Jensen">Jensen, Cheryl (1999). "Tupí–Guaraní". In ''The Amazonian Languages'', eds. R. M. W. Dixon and Alexandra Y. Aikhenvald, pp. 125–163. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Pg. 126</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/jaguar |title=Jaguar |work=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2008-12-25}}</ref> ;[[Jaguarundi]] [[wikt:jaguarundi|†]]: from [[Guaraní language|Guaraní]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. ;[[Maraca]] [[wikt:maraca|†]]: from [[Tupi language|Tupí]] ''maraka'' via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. ;[[Macaw]] [[wikt:macaw|†]]: via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''Macau'' from [[Tupi language|Tupi]] ''macavuana,'' which may be the name of a type of palm tree the fruit of which the birds eat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=macaw|title=macaw - Origin and meaning of macaw by Online Etymology Dictionary|website=www.etymonline.com}}</ref> ;[[Manioc]] [[wikt:manioc|†]]: from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] man(d)ioca through [[French language|French]] {{IPA|/maniˈʔok-/}}.<ref name="Jensen" /> ;[[Petunia]] [[wikt:petunia|†]]: from [[Tupi language|Tupí]] ''petun'' 'smoke' via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. ;[[Piranha]] [[wikt:piranha|†]]: from [[Tupi language|Tupí]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]].<ref>RHD (1987:1475)</ref> ;[[Seriema]] [[wikt:seriema|†]]:from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] ''siriema'' 'the crested one' via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ;[[Tapioca]] [[wikt:tapioca|†]]: from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] {{IPA|/tɨpɨˈʔok-a/}},<ref name="Jensen" /> "juice squeezed out".<ref>Bright (2004:480)</ref> ;[[Tapir]] [[wikt:tapir|†]]: from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] tapir through [[French language|French]] {{IPA|/tapiˈʔir-/}}.<ref name="Jensen" /> ;[[Tegu]] [[wikt:tegu|†]]: from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] ''teiú-guaçú'' 'big lizard' via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] teiú ;[[Toucan]] [[wikt:toucan|†]]: from [[Old Tupi language|Tupinambá]] via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] tucano through [[French language|French]] {{IPA|/tuˈkan-/}},<ref name="Jensen" /> via [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[French language|French]].<ref>RHD (1987:2001)</ref>
==Words from other indigenous languages of the Americas== ;[[Abalone]] [[wikt:abalone|†]]: from [[Rumsen language|Rumsen]] ''awlun'' and [[Ohlone]] ''aluan'', via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''abulón.''<ref>Bright (2004:19)</ref> ;[[Alpaca]] [[wikt:alpaca|†]]: from [[Aymara language|Aymara]] ''allpaka'', via [[Spanish language|Spanish]].<ref>{{OEtymD|alpaca|accessdate=2009-06-21}}</ref> ;[[Appaloosa]] [[wikt:appaloosa|†]]: Either named for the [[Palouse River]], whose name comes from [[Sahaptin language|Sahaptin]] ''palú:s'', "what is standing up in the water"; or for [[Opelousas, Louisiana]], which may come from [[Choctaw language|Choctaw]] ''api losa'', "black body".<ref>Bright (2004:45)</ref> ;[[Bayou]] [[wikt:bayou|†]]: from early [[Choctaw language|Choctaw]] ''bayuk'', "creek, river", via [[French language|French]].<ref>Bright (2004:61)</ref> ;[[Camassia|Camas]] [[wikt:camas|†]]: from [[Nez Perce language|Nez Perce]] {{IPA|qémʼes}}.<ref>Alan H. Hartley. [http://www.d.umn.edu/~ahartley/CAMAS_etymology.pdf The Inland Etymology of ''Camas''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225135709/http://www.d.umn.edu/~ahartley/CAMAS_etymology.pdf |date=2011-12-25 }}</ref> ;[[Cannibal]] [[wikt:cannibal|†]]: via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''Caníbalis'', from a [[Cariban languages|Cariban language]], meaning "person, Indian",<ref>{{cite web
