|publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/h/h0266100.html |title=Hooch |publisher=[[American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |accessdate=2007-05-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929111129/http://www.yourdictionary.com/ahd/h/h0266100.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-29}}</ref> <!--;[[Iktus]] [[wikt:Iktus|†]]: from [[Chinook Jargon|Chinook Trade Jargon]] {{IPA|[XXX]}}, from XXX ''XXX''.<ref name="auto"/>--> ;[[Kachina]] [[wikt:kachina|†]]: from [[Hopi language|Hopi]] ''katsína'', "spirit being".<ref>Bright (2004:194)</ref> ;[[Kiva]] [[wikt:kiva|†]]: from [[Hopi language|Hopi]] ''kíva'' (containing ''ki-'', "house").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/kiva |title=Kiva |publisher=Dictionary.com |accessdate=2009-04-13}}</ref> ;[[Kokanee salmon|Kokanee]] [[wikt:kokanee|†]]: perhaps from [[Salishan languages|Twana]] ''kəknǽxw.''<ref>Bright (2004:232)</ref> ;[[Manatee]] [[wikt:manatee|†]]: via [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''manatí'', from a word in a [[Cariban languages|Cariban language]] meaning "(woman's) breast".<ref>Simpson, George Gaylord (1941). "Vernacular Names of South American Mammals". ''Journal of Mammalogy'' '''22'''.1:14</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/manatee |title=Manatee |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{OEtymD|manatee|accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref> ;[[Ohunka]]: from [[Lakota language|Lakota]] "false", "untrue".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.lakotawritings.com/lakota_words_Index.htm |title = Lakota Words Index |author = |publisher = Lakota Writings |accessdate = 2010-01-13 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/60w6LnApe?url=http://www.lakotawritings.com/lakota_words_Index.htm |archive-date = 2011-08-14 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> ;[[Piki]] [[wikt:Piki|†]]: from [[Hopi language|Hopi]]. ;[[Pogonip]] [[wikt:Pogonip|†]]: from [[Shoshone language|Shoshone]] {{IPA|/pakɨnappɨ/}} ({{IPA|[paˈɣɨnappɨ̥]}}), "fog".<ref>Bright (2004:389)</ref> ;[[Poncho]] [[wikt:poncho|†]]: via Spanish from [[Mapudungun]] ''pontho'',<ref>{{OEtymD|poncho|accessdate=2008-07-07}}</ref> "woolen fabric".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/poncho |title=Poncho |publisher=Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary |accessdate=2008-07-07}}</ref> ;[[Potato]]: via Spanish ''patata'' from Haitian Carib ''batata''="sweet potato"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=potato|title=potato - Origin and meaning of potato by Online Etymology Dictionary|website=www.etymonline.com}}</ref> ;[[Potlatch]] [[wikt:potlatch|†]]: from [[Nuu-chah-nulth language|Nuuchahnulth]] (Nootka) ''p̉aƛp̉ač'' ({{IPA|[pʼatɬpʼat͡ʃ]}}, [[reduplication]] of ''p̉a'', "to make ceremonial gifts in potlatch", with the [[Aspect (linguistics)#Examples of various aspects rendered in English|iterative]] suffix ''-č'') via [[Chinook Jargon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50185464|title=Help - Oxford English Dictionary|publisher=}}</ref> <!--;[[Quiggly]] [[wikt:Quiggly|†]]: from [[Chinook Jargon|Chinook Trade Jargon]] {{IPA|[XXX]}}, from XXX ''XXX'' meaning "down" or "underneath" or "beneath".<ref name="auto"/>--> ;[[Salal]] [[wikt:salal|†]]: from [[Chinook Jargon|Chinook Trade Jargon]] {{IPA|[səˈlæl]}}, from [[Chinookan languages|Lower Chinook]] ''salál''.<ref>Bright (2004:416)</ref> ;[[Saguaro]] [[wikt:saguaro|†]]: via [[Spanish language|Spanish]], from some indigenous language, possibly [[Opata language|Opata]].<ref>RHD (1987:1691)</ref> ;[[Bigfoot|Sasquatch]] [[wikt:sasquatch|†]]: From [[Halkomelem language|Halkomelem]] {{IPA|[ˈsæsqʼəts]}}.<ref>Bright (2004:422)</ref> ;[[Calochortus nuttallii|Sego]] [[wikt:sego|†]]: from [[Ute language|Ute-Southern Paiute]] {{IPA|/siˈkuʔa/}} ({{IPA|[siˈɣuʔa]}}).<ref>Bright (2004:429)</ref> ;[[Sequoia (genus)|sequoia]] [[wikt:sequoia|†]]: from a [[Cherokee language|Cherokee]] personal name, <Sikwayi>, with no further known etymology.<ref>Bright (2004:432)</ref> ;[[Sockeye salmon|Sockeye]] [[wikt:sockeye|†]]: from [[Halkomelem language|Halkomelem]] {{IPA|/ˈsθəqəʔj/}}.<ref>Bright (2004:455)</ref> ;[[Skookum]] [[wikt:skookum|†]]: from [[Chinook Jargon]] {{IPA|[ˈskukəm]}}, "powerful, supernaturally dangerous", from [[Salishan languages|Lower Chehalis]] ''skʷəkʷə́m'', "devil, anything evil, spirit monster".<ref>Bright (2004:452)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/skookum |title=Skookum |publisher=Dictionary.com |accessdate=2007-03-29}}</ref> ;[[Tamarin]] [[wikt:tamarin|†]]: from a [[Cariban languages|Cariban language]], via [[French language|French]].<ref>RHD (1987:1939)</ref> ;[[Tipi]] [[wikt:tipi|†]]: from [[Lakota language|Lakota]] ''thípi'', "house".<ref name="Bright 2004:489"/> ;[[Tupelo]] [[wikt:tupelo|†]]: Perhaps from [[Creek language|Creek]] ''’topilwa'', "swamp-tree", from ''íto'', "tree" + ''opílwa'', "swamp".<ref>RHD (1987:2036)</ref> ;[[Sagittaria|Wapatoo]] [[wikt:wapatoo|†]]: from [[Chinook Jargon]] {{IPA|[ˈwapato]}}, "arrowroot, wild potato", from [[Chinookan languages|Upper Chinook]] {{IPA|[wa]-}}, a noun prefix + {{IPA|[pato]}}, which comes from [[Kalapuyan languages|Kalapuyan]] {{IPA|[pdóʔ]}}, "wild potato".<ref>Bright (2004:547)</ref> ;[[Wakinyan]] [[wikt:wakinyan|†]]: from [[Lakota language|Lakota]] ''wa'', "people/things" + ''kiŋyaŋ'', "to fly".<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Wakinyan.html?id=bRzLf19XLHsC | title=Wakinyan: Lakota Religion in the Twentieth Century | publisher=U of Nebraska Press | date=Mar 1, 2001 | accessdate=April 5, 2013 | author=Feraca, Stephen E.| isbn=978-0803269057 }}</ref> ;[[Yaupon]] [[wikt:yaupon|†]]: from [[Catawba language|Catawba]] ''yąpą'', from ''yą'', "wood/tree" + ''pą'', "leaf".<ref>RHD (1987:2200)</ref>
==See also== *[[List of placenames of indigenous origin in the Americas]] *[[List of place names in Canada of Aboriginal origin]] *[[List of place names in New England of aboriginal origin]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2016}} This is a list of prominent people who were born in [[Dagbon Kingdom|Dagbon]], lived for a significant period in [[Dagomba people|Dagbon]] or were born to a [[Dagbani language|Dagomba]] parent or parents.
==Arts== [[File:SamataAngelAward08.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Samata Angel|Samata Abudulai]]]] *[[Abubakari Lunna]] *[[Awal Alhassan]] *[[Samata Angel]]
==Education== * Sampahi-Naa [[Abdallah Zablong Zakariah]], professor of African history from the Institute of African Studies at the [[University of Ghana]].<ref name="tufts">{{cite web | url=http://www.tuftsdaily.com/world-damba-festival-celebrates-northern-ghanaian-culture-1.2764294#.UzFH8oVFf1U | title=World Damba Festival celebrates northern Ghanaian culture | publisher=The Tufts Daily | work=Nina Goldman | date=September 17, 2012 | accessdate=25 March 2014 | author=Josh, Weiner}}</ref> *[[Abdulai Iddrisu]], professor of history, [[St. Olaf College]], [[Minnesota]] and a fellow of the Institute for the Study of Islamic Thought in Africa (ISITA), [[Northwestern University]], [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://wp.stolaf.edu/history/abdulai-iddrisu/ | title=Abdulai Iddrisu | publisher=St. Olaf College | accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> * [[Haruna Yakubu]] * [[Ismael Musah Montana]], professor of history at [[Northern Illinois University]] and a visiting professor at [[Trent University]], [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://stambeli.com/Stambeli.com/Mediatheque/Entrees/2011/6/17_Ismael_Musah_Montana.html | title=Ismael Musah Montana profile | publisher=Stambell | accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://northernstar.info/city/article_1308a5e6-8c8c-11e3-8b8f-001a4bcf6878.html | title=Black Heritage Month kicks off | publisher=Northern Star | date=February 2, 2014 | accessdate=25 March 2014 | author=Stoney Stone}}</ref> * [[R. P. Baffour]]<!--, past vice Chancellor of [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]]--> *[[Seidu Al-hassan]], Agricultural Economist and Director of the Institute for Continuing Education and Interdisciplinary Research (CCEIR) at the [[University for Development Studies]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://m.peacefmonline.com/pages/news/education/201304/161146.php | title=UDS incorporates UNDP's human development courses in its curriculum | publisher=PeaceFmOnline | date=14 April 2013 | accessdate=29 May 2014}}</ref>
==Entertainment== [[File:Rocky Dawuni.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Rocky Dawuni]]]] * [[Rascalimu]] * [[Rocky Dawuni]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleancookstoves.org/media-and-events/press/global-alliance-for-clean-cookstoves-names-rocky-dawuni-as-ambassador.html|title=GLOBAL ALLIANCE FOR CLEAN COOKSTOVES NAMES ROCKY DAWUNI AS AMBASSADOR!|publisher=Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves|date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldmusiccentral.org/2013/05/18/ghanaian-reggae-and-afrobeat-star-rocky-dawuni-to-perform-in-europe/|title=Ghanaian Reggae and Afrobeat Star Rocky Dawuni to perform in Europe|publisher=World Music Central|date=18 May 2013 |accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.ke.msn.com/features/rocky-dawuni-from-ghana-with-so-much-reggae-2|title=Rocky Dawuni: From Ghana with so much Reggae|publisher=MSN Entertainment|date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodbowl.com/philpedia/rocky-dawuni|title=Walt Disney Concert Hall: Rocky Dawuni|publisher=HollyWood Bowl|date= 25 May 2010|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref> <!-- International [[Reggae]] music star,Ambassador of [[United Nations]] Global Alliance Foundation at the forefront of the fight for [[Social justice]] and the promotion of world peace across the global stage.and renowned [[Activism|Humanitarian Activist]]--> * [[Sidiku Buari]] * [[Sheriff Ghale]] * [[Nuru_(musician)]] * [[Sherifa Gunu]] * [[Fancy Gadam]]; afropop, dancehall and reggae musical artiste.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.graphic.com.gh/entertainment/showbiz-news/fancy-gadam-storms-the-national-theatre.html|title=Fancy Gadam storms the National Theatre - Graphic Online|last=Duah|first=Kofi|website=www.graphic.com.gh|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-03-07}}</ref>
==Information Communication Technology== * [[Mohammed-Sani Abdulai]], Computer Scientist and Informatics researcher.
==Law== * Ibrahim Mahama, Lawyer and Opinion Leader in [[Dagomba people|Dagbon]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/news/408499/1/lawyer-ibrahim-mahama-expresses-shock-at-president.html|title=Lawyer Ibrahim Mahama expresses shock at President Mills death|publisher=www.modernghana.com|date=28 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref> as well as a leading member of the [[Convention People's Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ghanaweb.com/mobile/wap.small/news.article.php?ID=7001|title=Alhaji Ibrahim Mahama joins CP Presidential race|publisher=www.ghanaweb.com|date=10 June 1999 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref>
==Media== * [[Alhassan Suhuyini|Alhassan S. Suhuyini]] * [[Mahama Shaibu]]
==Military & Police== * [[Bawa Andani Yakubu]]
==Politics== [[File:Alhaji Aliu Mahama.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Aliu Mahama]]]] * [[Aliu Mahama]]<!--, 3rd [[Vice President of Ghana|Vice President]] of the 4th Republic of [[Ghana]].--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/news/431171/1/aliu-mahama-was-ghanas-first-muslim-vice-president.html |title=Aliu Mahama Was Ghana's First Muslim Vice President |publisher=www.ModernGhana.com |date=19 November 2002 |accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref> * [[Imoro Yakubu Kakpagu]] * [[Muntaka Mohammed Mubarak]] * [[Muhammad Mumuni|Alhaji Muhammad Mumuni]] * [[Ras Mubarak]] * [[A.B.A Fuseni]] * [[Inusah Fuseni]]
==Religious== * [[Yusuf Soalih Ajura]]<!--, founder of [[Sunni Islam|Ahlu Sunnah wal Jamaah]] [[Wahhabi movement|movement]] in Ghana as well as the pacesetter [[Ambariya Islamic Institute|Ambariya Sunni Community]] headquartered in [[Tamale, Ghana|Tamale]].--><ref>{{cite web|url= |title=Ghana Studies Council Newsletter: Issue 16 |publisher=University of California, Riverside |author=Ray Kea|date=September 2003 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= |title=Islamic Radicalisation and Violence in Ghana |publisher=ESRC Ghana Country Study |author=Mustapha Abdallah & Kwesi Aning|date= }}</ref> * [[Saeed Abubakr Zakaria]] * [[Mariam Alhassan Alolo]]
==Science== * Dr. M. I. Iddrisu, [[Neurosurgeon]] at [[Korle Bu Teaching Hospital]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medpages.co.za/sf/index.php?page=person&personcode=205435&keywords=Medical%20professionals%20-%20Neurosurgeon,%20Ghana|title=List of Neurosurgeons in Ghana|publisher=MedPages.co.za|date=23 August 2013 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> and Board Chairman for [[Tamale Teaching Hospital]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tamaleteachinghospital.org/about-us/governance/our-board/|title=Tamale Teaching Hospital Board|publisher=Tamale Teaching Hospital.org|date=23 August 2013 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> He is also a [[Senior Lecturer]] at the [[University of Ghana]] Medical School.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ug.edu.gh/hrodd/pdf/Staff_List_2011.pdf|title=Staff List - Uninversity of Ghana|publisher=University of Ghana|date=25 August 2013 |accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref>
==Sport== [[File:Уорис.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Abdul Majeed Waris]]]] * [[Abdul Majeed Waris]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanasoccernet.com/striker-waris-scores-debut-black-stars-goal-in-heavy-win-over-sudan|title=Striker Waris scores debut Black Stars Goal in heavy win over Sudan|publisher=Ghana Soccer Net|date=25 August 2013 |accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-au/people/ghana/71178/abdul-majeed-waris|title=Abdul Majeed Waris Bio|publisher=Goal.com |date=23 August 2013 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanafa.org|title=Ghana Football Association|publisher=GhanaFA.org|date=25 August 2013 |accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref><!--, [[Association football|Association Football]] striker for [[FC Spartak Moscow]] in the [[Russian Premier League]]. He plays for the [[Ghana national football team|Ghana National Football Team]] popularly known as the Black Stars.--> * [[Abukari Damba]] * [[Wakaso Mubarak]]
==Other== * [[Yakubu II]]
==See also== * [[Dagban yuya]]<!-- * [[Tamale, Ghana]] * [[Kumbungu (Ghana parliament constituency)|Kumbungu]] * [[Jisonaayili]] * [[Ambariya Sunni Community]]-->
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.dagbon.net/ Home for news, history, customs, and information about Dagbon and Northern Region of Ghana] * [http://sofifa.com/en/fifa13/player/149129-abdul-majeed-waris/ Online Fifa Database Searching] SoFifa * [http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=46530/ Ghana to establish Neurosurgery Centre] GhanaWeb * [http://www.ugms.edu.gh/ University of Ghana Medical School] University of Ghana * [http://conventionpeoplesparty.org/ Convention People's Party] * [http://ghanaweb.com/mobile/wap.small/news.article.php?ID=197596/ Unearth Kufuor¹S Evil Deeds Alhaji Mahama - Ghana Web] GhanaWeb * [http://www.rockydawuni.com/ Rocky Dawuni Official Website] * [http://www.unfoundation.org/what-we-do/campaigns-and-initiatives/ The United Nations Foundation: Working to Create a Better Tomorrow] United Nations * [https://www.facebook.com/RockyDawuniFilm/ Rocky Dawuni Biographical movie "Rocky Dawuni: Branches of the Same Tree".]

revision.text:
[[Image:NHDRCover.jpg|thumb|right|The 2006 NHDR for Lao]] The '''National Human Development Reports''' (NHDR) take the Global Human Development Report approach to the national level and are prepared and owned by national teams. More than 540 national and sub-national HDRs have been produced so far by 135 countries, in addition to 31 regional reports.
They have introduced the human development concept into national policy dialogue — not only through human development indicators and policy recommendations, but also through the country-led and country-owned process of consultation, research and report writing. Data that is often not published elsewhere - such as statistics disaggregated by geographic location, ethnic group or along rural/urban lines - help pinpoint development gaps, measure progress and flag early warning signs of possible conflict.
As advocacy tools designed to appeal to a wide audience, the reports also spur lively public debates and mobilize support for action and change. They have helped to articulate people’s perceptions and priorities, as well as serve as a resource of alternate policy opinion for development planning.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} ; Indices
* [[Measure of America|American Human Development Index]] * [[Bhutan GNH Index]] * [[Broad measures of economic progress]] * [[Disability-adjusted life year]] * [[Full cost accounting]] * [[Green national product]] * [[Green gross domestic product]] (Green GDP) * [[Gender-related Development Index]] * [[Genuine Progress Indicator]] (GPI) * [[Global Peace Index]] * [[Gross National Happiness]] * [[Gross National Well-being]] (GNW) * [[Happiness economics]] * [[Happy Planet Index]] (HPI) * [[Human Development Index]] (HDI) * [[ISEW]] (Index of sustainable economic welfare) * [[Legatum Prosperity Index]] * [[Leisure satisfaction]] * [[Living planet index]] * [[Law of Social Cycle]] * [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs) * [[Money-rich, time-poor]] * [[OECD Better Life Index]] BLI * [[Subjective life satisfaction]] * [[Where-to-be-born Index]] * [[Wikiprogress]] * [[World Happiness Report]] (WHR) * [[World Values Survey]] (WVS)
; Other * [[Economics]] * [[Democracy Ranking]] * [[Demographic economics]] * [[Economic development]] * [[Ethics of care]] * [[Human Development and Capability Association]] * [[Human Poverty Index]] * [[Progress (history)]] * [[Progressive utilization theory]] * [[Post-materialism]] * [[Psychometrics]] * [[International Association for Feminist Economics]] * [[International development]] * [[Sustainable development]] * [[System of National Accounts]] * [[Welfare economics]]

{{unsourced|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox Radio Station | name = Radio 1 | image = | area = Czech Republic | branding = | slogan = | airdate = | frequency = 91.9 [[Hertz|MHz]] | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = | language = Czech | power = | erp = | class = | callsign_meaning = | owner = | webcast = | website = {{url|www.radio1.cz}} }} '''Czech Radio 1''' is an [[alternative radio]] broadcasting company based in [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]], at 91.9 [[megahertz|MHz]] in and around the city. Having started out as a [[pirate radio|pirate station]], Radio 1 began broadcasting as a regular FM station in the spring of 1991, as the first privately owned Czech commercial radio station.{{cn|date=March 2018}} It is also popular amongst Czechs living abroad who listen to it online. It is a [[freeform (radio format)|freeform]] format.
==Content== Radio 1 mostly to focuses on [[alternative rock|alternative]] and independent music and culture of genres including [[electronic music|electronic]], [[rock music|rock]], [[jazz]], [[reggae]], and [[ambient music|ambient]], rather than [[pop music]]. The station has about 30 specialist shows including ''Blue Train'' (jazz session), ''CD Nonstop'' (a whole CD recording is played every day), ''Film o páté'' ("Film at Five" - a program about current movies), ''French Connection'' (news from the alternative [[Music of France|French music]] scene), Hard Music ([[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] and related music program), ''Hitparáda Radia 1'' ("the hit parade of Radio 1" - foreign music top 40), ''Knižní servis'' ("the book service" - a discussion of new books), ''Reggae club'' ([[reggae]]), ''Shadowbox'' (news from the [[Drum and bass]] scene), ''Velká sedma'' ("the great seven" - Czech music [[hit parade]]), ''Všechny hudby světa'' ("all music of the world" - [[world music]] program) or ''Zátiší'' ("the still life" - discussion program with invited guests). It is one of few Czech radio stations to have shows with English speaking presenters.
==External links== *[http://www.radio1.cz/ Czech Radio 1]
[[Category:Radio stations in the Czech Republic]]

The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Awka''' ({{lang-la|Avkaën(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Awka]], [[Anambra State]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Onitsha|Onitsha]] in [[Nigeria]]. It boosts of having the highest number of priests in Africa as a whole.
==History== * November 10, 1977: Established as Diocese of Awka from the Metropolitan Archdiocese of Onitsha
==Special churches== The [[Cathedral]] is St. Patrick’s Cathedral in [[Awka]].
== Leadership ==
* [[Bishop]]s of Awka (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Albert Kanene Obiefuna]] (10 November 1977 Appointed - 9 September 1994 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Onitsha|Coadjutor Archbishop of Onitsha]]) ** Bishop [[Simon Akwali Okafor]] (9 September 1994 Appointed - 17 April 2010 Retired) ** Bishop Paulinus Chukwuemeka Ezeokafor (8 July 2011 – present)
== See also == * [[Roman Catholicism in Nigeria]]

The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Otukpo''' ({{lang-la|Otukpoën(us)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Otukpo]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Abuja|Abuja]] in [[Nigeria]].
==History== * July 10, 1995: Established as Diocese of Otukpo from the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Makurdi|Diocese of Makurdi]]. The first bishop of the diocese is Late Most Revd. Fidelis Ogah Orgah.
==Special churches== The [[Cathedral]] is St Francis’ Cathedral in Otukpo.
==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Makurdi (Roman rite) ** Bishop Michael Ekwoyi Apochi (since December 17, 2002) ** Bishop [[Fidelis Uga Orgah]] (July 10, 1995 – December 7, 2000)

[[Tad (given name)|Tad]] | name day = | derived = | popularity = | footnotes = }} '''Tadas''' is a [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] masculine [[given name]]. It is a cognate of the name [[Thaddeus]] and may refer to: *[[Tadas Blinda]] (1846–1877), Lithuanian folk hero of the 19th century *[[Tadas Gražiūnas]] (born 1978), Lithuanian footballer *[[Tadas Ivanauskas]] (1882–1971), Lithuanian zoologist, biologist and a founder of Vytautas Magnus University *[[Tadas Kijanskas]] (born 1985), Lithuanian footballer *[[Tadas Klimavičius]] (born 1982), Lithuanian basketball player *[[Tadas Kumeliauskas]] (born 1990), Lithuanian ice hockey player *[[Tadas Labukas]] (born 1984), Lithuanian footballer *[[Tadas Langaitis]] (born 1977), Lithuanian civic activist and entrepreneur *[[Tadas Murnikas]] (born ????), Lithuanian cyclist and Olympic competitor *[[Tadas Papečkys]] (born 1978), Lithuanian footballer *[[Tadas Šuškevičius]] (born 1985), Lithuanian race-walker and Olympic competitor '''As a middle name:''' *[[Linas Tadas Karosas]] (born 1964), Lithuanian businessman and entrepreneur [[Category:Lithuanian masculine given names]] {{given name}} {{given-name-stub}} {{Lithuania-stub}}

The '''Taranaki Basin''' is an onshore-offshore [[Cretaceous]] [[rift]] basin on the West Coast of [[New Zealand]].{{cite journal|last1=Baur|first1=Jan|last2=Sutherland|first2=Rupert|last3=Stern|first3=Tim|title=Anomalous passive subsidence of deep-water sedimentary basins: a prearc basin example, southern New Caledonia Trough and Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=Basin Research|date=2014|volume=26|issue=2|pages=242–268|doi=10.1111/bre.12030}}{{cite journal|last1=Higgs|first1=K.E.|last2=King|first2=P.R.|last3=Raine|first3=J.I.|last4=Sykes|first4=R.|last5=Browne|first5=G.H.|last6=Crouch|first6=E.M.|title=Sequence stratigraphy and controls on reservoir sandstone distribution in an Eocene marginal marine-coastal plain fairway, Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=[[Marine and Petroleum Geology]] |date=2012|volume=32| pages=110–137 |doi=10.1016/j.marpetgeo.2011.12.001}} Development of rifting was the result of extensional stresses during the breakup of [[Gondwana]]land. The basin later underwent fore-arc and [[intra-arc basin]] development, due to the subduction of the Pacific Plate under the Australian Plate at the [[Hikurangi Trench|Hikurangi Subduction System]].{{cite journal|last1=Walcott|first1=R.I.|date=1987|title=Geodetic Strain and the Deformational History of the North Island of New Zealand during the late Cainozoic|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A|volume=373|issue=2037|accessdate=}} The basin covers approximately 100,000 km2 of which the majority is offshore. The basin contains mostly marine sediment, with significant terrestrial sediment from the Late Cretaceous to the Eocene.{{cite journal|last1=Sykes|first1=R.|last2=Volk|first2=H.|last3=George|first3=S.C.|last4=Ahmed|first4=M.|title=Marine influence helps preserve the oil potential of coaly source rocks: Eocene Mangahewa Formation, Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=Organic Chemistry|date=2014|volume=66|pages=140–163|doi=10.1016/j.orggeochem.2013.11.005}} The majority of New Zealand's oil and gas production occurs within the basin, with over 400 wells and approximately 20 oil and gas fields being drilled. [[File:Map and Cross Section of Taranaki Basin.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Broad Map and General Cross Section of the Taranaki Basin. Prepared by the Dept. of Lands and Survey. Source: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ).
[[Mount Taranaki]] is in the middle.]] ==Overview== The Taranaki Basin lies on the West coast of the North Island of New Zealand in the [[Taranaki Region]], and is approximately 400 km west of the current Pacific-Australian plate boundary. It covers approximately 100,000 km2 and contains up to 9 km in sediment. The basin is divided into two main components, the Western Platform and Eastern Mobile Belt, formerly known as the Taranaki Graben.{{Cite book|last1=Armstrong|first1=P.A.|last2=Chapman|first2=D.S.|title=Combining Tectonics and Thermal Fields in the Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=Geothermics in Basin Analysis|date=1999|pages=151–176|doi=10.1007/978-1-4615-4751-8_8|series=Computer Applications in the Earth Sciences|isbn=978-1-4613-7154-0}}{{cite journal|last1=Palmer|first1=Julie|last2=Geoff|first2=Bulte|title=Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=Active Margin Basins|date=1988|pages=269–290|doi=10.1306/M52531C9|doi-broken-date=2018-09-06}} The Western Platform is a relatively undeformed, stable block compared to the Eastern Mobile Belt. While it underwent block faulting throughout the Late Cretaceous to the Eocene, it has been stable since. This section of the basin contains between 2000 and 5000m of sediment, dating from the Late Cretaceous to present. The Western Platform is separated from the Eastern Mobile Belt on the East by the Cape Egmont fault zone, a northwest trending fault zone consisting of multiple subparallel reverse and normal faults. The Eastern Mobile Belt consists of multiple grabens and contains multiple compressional features, including overthrusts, reverse faults, and inversion structures. The Eastern Mobile Belt extends from this fault zone to the north-south trending Taranaki fault zone, which is adjacent to the a large upthrust basement block that divides the Taranaki Basin from the later-formed, eastward Wanganui Basin. ;Nature The [[Blue whale]], [[Southern right whale]] and the critically endangered [[Maui's dolphin]] are living beings in the sea in Taranaki Basin, or live near the coast of Taranaki. For the Blue whale it is a breeding ground.[https://www.greenpeace.org/new-zealand/press-release/rainbow-warrior-confronts-taranaki-oil-rigs/ Rainbow Warrior confronts Taranaki oil rigs’’], [[Greenpeace Aotearoa New Zealand|Greenpeace New Zealand]], October 2, 2018. ==Tectonic Evolution== ===Basement Structure=== Pre-rift rocks in the Taranaki Basin are typically considered [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]]. The Taranaki basement is extremely heterogeneous, with metasediments and granites representing the original Gondwana Craton, and granitoids, volcanic and volcano-sedimentary rocks, and accretionary complexes representing later accretionary terrains and plutons.{{cite journal|last1=Muir|first1=R.J|last2=Bradshaw|first2=J.D.|last3=Weaver|first3=S.D.|last4=Laird|first4=M.G.|title=The influence of basement structure on the evolution of the Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=Journal of the Geological Society|date=2000|volume=157|issue=6|pages=1179–1185|doi=10.1144/jgs.157.6.1179}} ===Rifting=== Formation of the Taranaki Basin initiated in the Late Cretaceous, due to the separation of Australia and [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]] during the breakup of [[Gondwana]]land. This breakup caused the formation of the [[Tasman Sea]], along with multiple extensional basins on the New Zealand subcontinent, including an intra-plate rift that formed the Taranaki Rift, which would develop into the Taranaki Basin.{{cite journal|last1=Kroeger|first1=K.F.|last2=Funnell|first2=R.H.|last3=Nicol|first3=A.|last4=Fohrmann|first4=M.|last5=Bland|first5=K.J.|last6=King|first6=P.R.|title=3D crustal-scale heat-flow regimes at a developing active margin (Taranaki Basin, New Zealand)|journal=Tectonophysics|date=2013|volume=591|pages=175–193|doi=10.1016/j.tecto.2012.04.005}}{{cite journal|last1=Thrasher|first1=G.P.|title=Last Cretaceous Geology of Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=Victoria University of Wellington: Thesis|date=1992|hdl=10063/525}} Syn-rift sediments were deposited within rift controlled grabens across the basin, and are separated from the basement rock by a regional unconformity. These sedimentary layers contain faulting that is indicative of extension during deposition. They include sequencing from non-marine conglomerates to sand, silt, and then coals.{{cite journal|last1=Webster|first1=Mark|last2=O'Conner|first2=Stephen|last3=Pindar|first3=Bitrus|last4=Swarbrick|first4=Richard|title=Overpressures in the Taranaki Basin: Distribution, causes, and implications for exploration|journal=American Association of Petroleum Geologists|date=2011|volume=95|issue=3|pages=339–379|doi=10.1306/06301009149}} ===Drift=== After the end of extension in the Late Cretaceous, the Taranaki Basin became a passive margin setting, with drift resulting in marine transgression. Subsidence of the basin was slow enough to allow for the massive accumulation of sediment during the Paleocene and Eocene. These Paleocene and Eocene sandstones contain the majority of the petroleum reserves found within the basin. During drift, a decline in sediment deposition occurred, with a thinning of layers from the Cretaceous to the Eocene. The sediments in this sequence lead from coastal plain deposits, to shallow marine sands, to shelf sediments. ==Stratigraphy== ===Pakawau Group=== The Pakawau group contains the oldest sediment within the Taranaki Basin, deposited between the Late Cretaceous and Paleocene. It includes the Rakopi Formation (85-75 Ma) and the North Cape Formation (75-65 Ma). Rocks within this group include fluvial sandstones and marine, transgressive sandstones. In some areas within the basin, this group is more than 2000 m thick. It overlies the mostly igneous and metasedimentary basement.{{cite journal|last1=Palmer|first1=Julie|title=Pre-Miocene lithostratigraphy of Taranaki Basin, New Zealand|journal=New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics|date=1985|volume=28|issue=2|pages=197–216|doi=10.1080/00288306.1985.10422220}} ===Kapuni Group=== The Kapuni group contains multiple formations that span the Paleocene and Eocene. These formations are, in ascending order, the Farewell Formation, Kaimiro Formation, Mangahewa Formation, and McKee Formation. The '''Farewell Formation''' (65-55 Ma) contains mostly fluvial sandstone. The '''Kaimiro Formation''' (55-45 Ma) contains mostly poor to moderately sorted alluvial and coastal plain sandstones with some inter-bedded micaceous and carbonaceous mudstones and siltstones. This formation is not fossiliferous. The '''Mangahewa Formation''' (45-34 Ma) consists mostly of sandstone, siltstone, mudstone and bitumonous coal. This formation has good reservoir sandstones. The '''McKee Formation''' (38-33 Ma) is easily recognizable by its coarse-grained, well sorted sandstones. Small clasts of mudstones and coal can be found throughout this formation. ===Tikorangi Limestone=== The Tikorangi Limestone (33-23 Ma) is composed of mostly sandy, deep-water limestone along with calcareous mudstone interbedded with calcareous sandstone.{{cite journal|last1=Fohrmann|first1=M.|last2=et. al.|title=Seismic reflection character, mapping and tectono-stratigraphic history of the Kupe area (4D Taranaki Project), south-eastern Taranaki Basin|journal=GNS Science Report|date=2012|url=http://www.gns.cri.nz/static/pubs/2012/SR%202012-36%20Kupe%20Mapping%20Report%20final.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2015}} It forms a conformable contact with an 8m thick layer of glauconitic sandstone, '''The Matapo Sandstone Member''', which lies above the formation. ===Mahoenui Group=== The Mahoenui Group consists of calcareous mudstones, with thinly interbedded sandstones, siltstones, and limestones. Sediment in this group was deposited during the Late Oligocene and the Early Miocene. ===Mokau Group=== The Mokau Group is composed of shoreface sandstones with some interbedded siltstones. Layers of fluvial conglomerate and coal can be found as well.{{cite book |last1=Kamp|first1=P.J.|last2=Vonk|first2=A.J.|last3=Nelson|first3=Campbell|chapter=Field Trip 5: Stratigraphic Architecture and Sedimentology of King Country and Eastern Taranaki Basins |title=Field Trip Guides, Geological Society of New Zealand, New Zealand Geophysical Society, 26th Annual Geothermal Workshop, Joint Geosciences Conference |location=New Zealand |publisher=Geological Society of New Zealand|date=2004|pages=43–86|accessdate=}} The sediment in this group represents deposition in the Early Miocene. ===Wai-iti Group=== The '''Mohakatino Formation''' (~17-13 Ma) is composed of silty mudstones, with andesitic, volcaniclastic sandstones. The '''Mt Messenger Formation''' (11-9 Ma), also known as the Waikiekie Formation, is a massive sandstone unit.{{cite journal|last1=Collen|first1=J.D.|last2=Neall|first2=V.E.|last3=Johnston|first3=J.H.|title=Sandstone xenoliths in the Pungarehu Formation, Western Taranaki, New Zealand: implications for petroleum exploration|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of New Zealand|date=1985|volume=15|issue=2|pages=201–212|doi=10.1080/03036758.1985.10416844}} The '''Urenui Formation''' (9-5 Ma) is a silty mudstone that contains occasional conglomerates. ===Matemateaonga Formation=== The Matemateaonga Formation (7-5 Ma) consists of shellbeds, siltstones and sandstones with interbedded conglomerate. This formation represents deposition during the Late Miocene and Early Pliocene.{{cite journal|last1=Vonk|first1=A.J.|last2=Kamp|first2=P.J.|title=Late Miocene-Early Pliocene Matemateaonga Formation in Eastern Taranaki Peninsula: A New 1:50,000 Geologic Map and Stratigraphic Framework|journal=New Zealand Petroleum Conference Proceedings|date=2004|accessdate=}} ===Recent Deposits=== Andesitic volcanism began within the basin in the Miocene, and has continued until the present day. ==Hydrocarbons== The majority of New Zealand's petroleum production has been within the Taranaki Basin. Over 1.8 billion barrels of [[Barrel of oil equivalent|BOE]] have been discovered, of which 70% is gas. More than 400 wells have been drilled throughout the basin, in about 20 fields. A wide variety of petroleum play types, mostly structural, can be seen throughout the basin due to its complex history. The main trap styles found within the basin are fault-dependent closures, inversion anticlines, and overthrusts. ;Source Rocks The majority of oil produced from the Taranaki basement are sourced from coals and marine shales from the Late Cretaceous and Paleogene. Current oil and gas fields within the basin {{cite book|title=New Zealand Petroleum Basins|date=2014|publisher=New Zealand Petroleum & Minerals : Ministry of Business|location=New Zealand|pages=2–103|url=http://www.nzpam.govt.nz/cms/about-nzpam/publications/new-zealand-petroleum-basins-part-one.pdf}} *Mangahewa Field *[[Maui gas field|Maui Field]] *[[Kapuni|Kapuni Field]] *Cardiff/Radno Field *Turangi/Ohanga Field *[[Pohokura field|Pohokura Field]] *[[McKee field|McKee Field]] *Tuhua Field *Tui Oil Field *[[Kupe field|Kupe Field]] *Rimu Field *[[Maari oil field|Maari Field]] *Kaimiro Field *Cheal Field *Moturoa Field *Karewa Field *Ngatoro Field *Waihapa Field *Toko Field ==See also== *[[Geology of Taranaki]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Oceanic features of Zealandia|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Zealandia]] [[Category:Geology of New Zealand]] [[Category:Taranaki]]
